business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Alister McMullin) took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - My question is directed to the Minister for Customs and Excise. I refer to a question which I asked of him yesterday and which he answered but he then corrected the answer last night. The question related to the resignation of Mr Hoffmann. I ask the Minister: Will he, before question time tomorrow, check again the answers which he has given to the Senate? In particular, will he check whether Mr Hoffmann ever did tender a resignation to the Department of Customs and Excise or whether a resignation was prepared for him by the Department? Will he check the date on which that was actually done and will he tell the Senate when Mr Hoffmann was informed that his resignation was accepted?

- Mr President,I know very well the deep concern of the honourable senator about this question relating to persecution of an individual by left wing members. I corrected the answer I gave yesterday as soon as I found out from Hansard that I had incorrectly answered the question. Everybody knows that I did this; everybody knows that that was my right and that it was the right thing to do. In relation to the question as to when the resignation was initially received from Mr Hoffmann by the Public Service Board or by the Department of Customs and Excise, that date remains the same as I gave in my statement and is the date that we all agree with.

- I address my question to the Minister for Customs and Excise. It relates to a reply he gave yesterday about evasion of customs duty, indicating that a number of charges and prosecutions were in hand. Can the Minister say whether this evasion has been very extensive. What are the details of it?
- When I was asked a similar question yesterday I mentioned that customs duty had been evaded.
- It was a considerable amount.

- lt was a considerable amount. I want to say now that the goods involved were cigarettes and tobacco. This case had nothing to do with the Hoffmann case. The officers have not been charged, but they have been reprimanded, and legal proceedings are being taken.

- I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry. In view of. the importance to our economy of the Government's protection to industry policy, plus the added work entailed by new procedures to .be undertaken by the Tariff Board, and having in mind resignations from the Board, which appear to be all too frequent, and the apparent difficulties the Minister has in rilling vacancies, will the Government give consideration firstly to increasing the full time membership of the Board and, secondly, to approving an increase in salaries commensurate with the very important work performed by the Board?

- The honourable senator prefaces his question by a general indication of the importance, magnitude and significance of the work of the Tariff Board. None of us would disagree with that proposition. Questions relating to the size of the Board and the emolument of its members are clearly matters that I shall have to refer to the Minister for Trade and Industry. I suggest that the honourable senator put his question on notice and I shall get a considered reply for him.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry. Has the Minister seen a statement made yesterday by the Chairman of the Hobart Marine Board that there were grim indications that unless determined action were taken events in the shipping world in the next few months could sound the death knell of the export industry of Tasmania? Will the Minister take immediate steps to convene a meeting of interested parties in Tasmania to ensure that

speech.para: Tasmania receives the same benefit from containerisation as will the mainland States?

talk.start.para: - This matter might well come within the portfolio of the Minister for Shipping and Transport. 1 think the logical thing to do is to direct the honourable senator's question to both the Minister for Trade and Industry and the Minister for Shipping and Transport. If we get two answers, then that will be all the better. But I shall certainly get an answer.

- I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in todays Australian Financial Review' referring to the steep increase in imports of New Zealand jam by Australia in the first seven months of the current financial year, wherein imports were stated to be 40 times greater than the total such imports for the whole of the year 1967-68? Is the Australian jam industry suffering an inordinately heavy economic handicap arising from the differential between sugar prices paid by Australian jam makers on the domestic market and the world market price paid by the New Zealand manufacturers? If so, what steps can be taken to ensure a reasonably competitive position for the local jam and fruit industries?

- This is a question which might better be directed to the Minister for Trade and Industry. Following a Press comment I was informed of some of the facts relating to this matter. It has been claimed that the local industry is at a severe disadvantage because of the cost of sugar to the Australian industry, which is $191.60 a ton compared with $94 a ton paid by the New Zealand industry for sugar used for export production. The degree of injury to the Australian jam industry has to be considered in terms of the quantum of trade at present between Australia and New Zealand. In that regard, the New Zealand component is a very small proportion of the Australian market. From June to December 1968. 271,000 Jb was imported from New Zealand, but in the same period 965,000 lb was imported from other countries. The

speech.para: Australian production in 1968 was 84,150,000 lb. That gives a very quick appreciation of the degree of injury that is allegedly being sustained because of this differential in the sugar price. There has been no industry request for increased duties. Jam does not come within the complex of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement, but if the industry suggested that it was being injured it would have the right to go to the Tariff Board to seek protection on the basis of that injury. That is a procedure that normally applies in these matters.

talk.start.para: - Has the Leader of the Government seen the announcements that motor car prices are expected to rise by as much as $100 in the very near future? In view of the large profits recently announced by a number of motor car firms - General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd announced a profit of more than $l0m last year - plus the fact that the Government last year forced a price increase in Japanese cars, what action does the Government intend to take to slop this increase, which obviously amounts to gross profiteering?

- I do not subscribe to the last sentence of the honourable senator's question in which he has expressed an opinion. I did see in a very quick way that there was to be an increase in the price of some motor vehicles, but I did not take on board the actual amount of the increase. I shall refer the question to the Minister for Trade and Industry for his comment. I feel bound to say, however, that we cannot simply take the profit of a company out of the air and say that because it amounted to $Xm then it must be profiteering. Profit must be considered in relation to capital investment and in terms of plant and machinery. It must be considered in relation to a whole host of accountancy problems before one can start making judgments as to whether the company is making a big profit, a reasonable profit or a small profit. To demonstrate the point further, there could be a situation in which a company made a profit of $10Om and that still would not be a reasonable profit in view of the capital costs involved in the undertaking.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. In view of the determination of Australian Labor Party politicians in South Australia to influence the people of our State against their own best interests with regard to the building of a new dam on the River Murray and, seemingly, for purely party political purposes, I ask: If the Chowilla Dam were to be built in South Australia, would South Australia get one jot more water than it has rights to at present under the existing River Murray Waters Agreement? ls it likely, when the Ministers of the three States concerned with the control of River Murray waters meet with the Commonwealth Minister on Friday, that the agreement which fixes the allocation of water for South Australia will be altered to allow more water to pass to South Australia if the Dartmouth dam is constructed?

- I must say that last night South Australian members of the great Australian Labor Party criticised the honourable senator quite severely in relation to her attitude of endeavouring to persuade the River Murray Commission, the Commonwealth Government and the States concerned that South Australia should be given the maximum amount of water possible. The River Murray Commission's technical advisers who met in 1961 and recommended Chowilla are now recommending Dartmouth. The reason that they now recommend Dartmouth is that it can provide for South Australia 0.86 million acre feet of water more than Chowilla. Consequently, at the meeting of Ministers to be held this Friday South Australia has a great opportunity to gain an increase in the amount of water it is to receive - something above the amount of only 1.254 million acre feet which Chowilla could provide. As a capacity of 0.86 million acre feet more water is planned for the Dartmouth dam than would be provided by a dam at Chowilla, that amount of water can be sent down the river to help South Australia. I am sure that the people of South Australia will be able to get an amount of water considerably in excess of the amount they would get from a dam at Chowilla.

- 1 direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Prior to the resignation of Mr G. C. Hoffmann from the Commonwealth Public Service were representations made to the Public Service Board on his behalf by Mr P. Cullen? Did Mr Cullen then hold any office on the staff of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives? What were the representations made by Mr Cullen to the Public Service Board? On what date were the representations made?

- If I were to answer the honourable senator's question I would be relying at this time on newspaper comment and the debate that took place in the Senate last night. I do know that Mr Cullen was at some stage a secretary to the Leader of the Opposition in the other place, but so that 1 can get a complete answer f. think the question should be put on the notice paper.
- He was on Mr Whitlam's staff.
- Yes.

- I desire to interrupt the series of arias from the 'Tales of Hoffman', which was written, appropriately enough, by Offenbach, to ask a question on a really important subject. Will the Minister for Supply comment on allegations made in a circular sent to senators by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom that Australia is linked with preparations for chemical and biological warfare and that the placing of an advertisement by the Department of Supply in January for a senior principal research scientist with a record of achievement, preferably in the study of the behaviour of compounds of biological significance and associated procedures, suggests that Australia may shortly be co-operating more fully in biological warfare7 Is the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom one more organisation where innocent and idealistic women are manipulated as a front by a shrewd minority coterie, behind the scenes, of Communists and extreme leftists?

- I received a copy of the circular referred to by the honourable senator. 1 have kept it in a folder after reading it with interest, since my name is mentioned in the second paragraph. I have had a reply prepared in anticipation that an honourable senator would ask me a question about it. The note I have on the subject states: The whole of the second paragraph of the circular - I have had a good look at this paragraph - draws a completely misleading inference. It is well known that Australia is a member of the technical co-operation programme with the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Canada, and that one field in which information is exchanged is chemical and biological defence. I have made it quite clear that it is Australia's policy to be well informed on defensive measures in this field, but not to have an offensive capability. A small group of scientists in Australia has the responsibility of keeping up to date our technology on advances in this field. Such knowledge is essential to the protection of the Australian people. The advertised position mentioned in the circular is in relation to work of a defence nature.
- Is the

speech.para: Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry aware that a contract negotiated by the Western Australian Potato Marketing Board to sell Ceylon 2,100 tons of seed potatoes is being jeopardised through lack of shipping space? Is the Minister aware also that this contract has been described as the forerunner of what could develop into the biggest potato deal ever negotiated by the Board and that it is in an area in which Western Australia has a natural freight advantage? In view of the fact that repealed requests to shipping companies throughout Australia, to the Department of Trade and Industry and to the Western Australian Department of Industrial Development have failed to obtain the required shipping space, will the Minister ask the Minister for Trade and Industry to take up this question as a matter of urgency?

talk.start.para: - I understand that the Department of Trade and Industry is in contact with the shipping lines, which are making every effort to lift the cargo by the due date specified in the contract. The Department's Western Australian office is keeping the shippers informed of developments. That is the information that I have to the moment. The honourable senator may want to put his question on notice so that he can obtain an answer which may supersede the answer I have given him. That is a matter of judgment for himself.

- My question is directed to the Minister for Customs and Excise, ls it a fact that his Department needs al least 100 additional officers to help smash syndicates handling the increasing entry of illicit drugs into Sydney? Is it a' fact also that the narcotics branch is gravely understaffed at present and finds it impossible to slop all illicit drug smuggling or lo keep the problem in check? Does the same situation prevail in other Australian ports? What action has been taken by the Department to overcome this very serious situation?

- I know of the honour-' able senator's concern about drug trafficking. I can tell him that there is not a shortage of 100 officers at Sydney. Within the past 3 years we have increased the staff of the prevention and detection service - they are the officers who handle this kind of work - by approximately 100% . We are equipping the officers with the latest gear, such as modern ships and means of transport, to help them in carrying out their duties. We are running schools to teach persons joining the Department the best methods of detecting people who are bringing in drugs on ships and so on. We haw turned our interest to the north of Australia in an endeavour to keep the drug problem at a minimum. In addition, recently in Canberra a meeting of State Ministers concerned and representatives of the police and health departments was held. I was the chairman of the meeting, lt was decided to set up a standing control committee to look into all the problems associated with drugs in Australia.

- I address my question to the Minister for Housing. Is it a fact that the maximum amount of S500 payable by the Government under the homes savings grant scheme has not been increased by one cent since its introduction on 2nd December 1963? Is it a fact also that this scheme was first announced in the Liberal-Country Party policy speech for the 1963 general election and that the only variations to it since then were contained in the 1966 policy speech? Does the Government believe that it was so extraordinarily generous in 1963 in granting $500 that this amount will absorb all building cost increases for the next 20 or 30 years and that there is no need to review frequently the sufficiency or adequacy of the $500? Does the Minister agree that this scheme appears to have taken its place with pensions and family allowances as levers to be manipulated solely at election time without regard for any social justice merits of the payments?
- That was a long question.
- It was a worthy one. full of merit.

- The honourable senator commented first of all that since the inception of this scheme the payment of the maximum grant of $500, which is a tax free gift to persons under 36 years of age who fulfil the required conditions and become eligible to receive it, had not been altered. This is correct. But I thought I also understood the honourable senator to say that the legislation had not been amended at all since it had been brought in.
- I did not say that.
- I beg the honourable senator's pardon. I was going to remind him that it had been amended on two occasions.
- I said in 1966 in the Government's policy speech.
- It was amended again, the honourable senator will recall, in 1967.
- The amount has not been altered.

- No, not the amount of $500. The honourable senator will recall that the limit for the value of house and land with improvements was increased from $14,000 to $15,000. 1 would remind Senator Gair also that when he speaks of this scheme he apparently feels that perhaps it is not doing a tremendously big work in assisting young people to get their own homes and also in assisting them in the field of saving.
- Do not attempt to read my thoughts; just answer the question.

- I think you will be pleased to know. Senator Gair, that since the inception of the scheme the grants paid out amount to S5S,458,980. These grants have been paid to 134,832 young couples who have benefitted from them. I believe that these figures show that this scheme is now not only doing a very fine work for these young persons who get the grant or whatever proportion of the grant they become eligible for but also it is benefitting them by saving. When we say (hat we have paid out this amount pf money, the Senate will recall that the Government pays $1 for every $3 saved by a young couple. This is a very great amount of money saved in the field of housing.
- What is the percentage increase in building costs?
- I can assure the honourable senator that this matter of the value of the housing grant, and other matters concerning this grant, of course are reviewed from time to time.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for External Territories. I ask: Is it a fact that the Minister for External Territories and the Administrator of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea shortly will announce the name of the consultant who will conduct the survey and later recommend the improvement pl'an for Port Moresby and the Territory of Papua and New Guinea? Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to the fact that honourable senators have pleaded with Ministers who have been called upon to make similar decisions that it is in the Australian public interest that firms be used which are truly Australian based and recognised as Australian firms? Can the Senate be assured that the Minister and the Cabinet are fired wilh the importance of establishing the confidence of Australian consultants, and indeed the regard of the world for Australian consultants, in the use by the Australian Government of Australian consultants?

- lt is the fact that the appointment of a consultant in town planning for Port Moresby is expected to be announced shortly. The point that the honourable senator makes, not for the first time, so enthusiastically, is well understood. But our purpose in Papua and New Guinea is not to be the torch bearer of the Australian flag per se. We will make an appointment of a person who has the most merit from the point of view of competence in town planning.

- Is the Minister for Customs and Excise aware of serious charges in last Sunday's Sydney 'Sunday Telegraph' that Federal members of parliament used their influence to prevent customs investigators carrying out inquiries into allegations that certain New South Wales police officers are running an international drug smuggling ring? Is it a fact that customs men were about to move and make arrests when they were instructed by a senior member of the Government to delay action? Will the Minister confirm or deny that he or any person in his Department instructed Mr Harvey Bate, the chief of the detection branch of the customs service in Sydney, to curtail certain action relating to Mr Bate's investigations into drug smuggling? If instructions of this nature have been given to Mr Bate, how can the Minister reconcile this serious impediment to his Department's determination to stop smuggling with his recent public announcements on (he same matter?

- I am aware of all the charges spoken of in last Sunday's newspapers. I say right here and now that the charge that members of parliament - not Ministers, but members of parliament - had interfered with customs officers to stop them doing their duty in relation to the drug traffic is a complete fabrication. To the best of our knowledge, there has not been one member of parliament who has intervened in the interests of drug peddlers in Australia.

- My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development, follows my previous question which was related to the attitude of the Labor Party in South Australia in influencing South Australians against their best interests. In view of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition in the South Australian Parliament has said publicly that if the waters of the Murray were to be impounded in a Chowilla reservoir, and therefore inside the South Australian borders, South Australia could simply help itself to the water when necessary, will the Minister explain the possible effects of such contemplated rebellious action by any future South Australian government?

- I have not seen in the Press any statement relating to the action that Mr Dunstan, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, may take, if the Chowilla Dam is built, to give water to South Australia in times of extreme drought - that is, by opening up the gates and letting the water go. All I can say to the honourable senator is that the River Murray Waters Agreement has been in existence for over 55 years and nobody - not even the Premier of a State - has broken that Agreement. Therefore, it would be the action of a completely irresponsible person if a Premier or any other person broke the Agreement so that a State could get water to which it was not entitled under the Agreement.

- I direct a question to Senator Anderson in his capacity of Leader of the Government in this chamber, not in his ministerial capacity otherwise, lt is a question which I do not ask him to refer to anyone else. Will he deny that the Government was involved in the stealing of commercial information from the Japanese embassy?

- I raise a point of order, firstly, on the basis of the framing of the question by the Leader of the Opposition and, secondly, on the basis that the Leader of the Opposition has no right to ask Senator Anderson in his personal capacity to give an opinion on matters that do not come within his ministerial responsibility.
- I directed the question to Senator Anderson as Leader of the Government.

- Order! I must admit, Senator Murphy, that it was an unusual question. That comes largely from your composing questions as you go along. I believe that that is where the trouble comes in. Lt makes it difficult at times to decide whether a question is in order. I will let this question go to Senator Anderson.

- As Leader of the Government in the Senate I answer questions relating to the management of the Senate. As Minister for Supply 1 answer questions relating to my Department. I represent the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for External Affairs. If it is within my competence to answer questions directed to me in relation to those portfolios I do so. If it is not within my competence I refer the questions to the Ministers concerned.

- I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will he deny that the Government was involved in the stealing of commercial information from the Japanese Embassy?
- I request that any question of that character, directed to the Prime Minister, be put on notice.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Science. Has the Minister seen any recent Press articles, some of which have appeared in Adelaide, which recount reports of young people holding degrees in arts or science who have been unable to obtain employment in line with their educational qualifications? Does the Minister agree with Professor Badger's statement that university courses, however abstract, should contain at least something realistically designed to fit in with what the student will have to do after graduation? Can the Minister say whether any attention has been given to this kind of inclusion so that the time, talent and money expended on the obtaining of university degrees will not be wasted?

- I have had my attention directed to Professors Badger's contribution to the Press on the subject referred to by Senator Davidson. I am informed that arts graduates who do not enter the teaching profession are having some difficulty in obtaining appropriate employment. About three quarters of the arts graduates of Australia enter the teaching profession. Nevertheless it is thought that there may be some merit in the Professor's suggestion that what I might call subjects of working experience be included in an arts degree course, and the Diploma of Education is a step in that direction. I hope there would not be one member of the Senate who would accept the proposition that the arts degree and its merits should be subordinated to economic purposes. It is hardly to be expected, as Professor Galbraith has suggested, that we would wish St Peter to ask those seeking entrance to Paradise: 'What was your contribution to the gross national product?'

- My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Government concerned about the threat of a coast to coast railway strike on Friday next? ls it not time that the whole system of arbitration in Australia was overhauled in the interests of industrial peace?

- Yes, Mr President, the Government is concerned about any industrial difficulty that arises in the Commonwealth because industrial strife affects everybody in the Commonwealth and it al'so affects our capacity as a nation. As to some variation of the industrial law which, by inference from the honourable senator's question, would resolve this threatened strike, I would not have a view. After all, changes in our industrial laws, so far as Commonwealth conciliation and arbitration are concerned, come to this place and are debated here. I think it is a complete over-simplification of the situation, or of any industrial situation, to suggest that some magical change in industrial law can be produced out of the bag overnight in order to resolve a strike that may occur next Friday.
- I ask the

speech.para: Minister for Customs and Excise whether his attention has been drawn to a reported statement of Mr H. C. Sleigh, chairman of H. C. Sleigh Ltd, to the effect that following the fixing of the price of indigenous crude oil in accordance with the formula announced by the Prime Minister late last year, a rise in the retail price of petrol is inevitable. Will the Minister say what anticipation he has as to the retail price of petrol following the fixing of the price of crude oil?

talk.start.para: - 1 know of considerable debate by various organisations and some companies on this subject of the price of oil and the fixing of the price of petrol following the new oil pricing agreement between the Prime Minister and Esso-BHP. Between now and the end of this year Esso-BHP will come into production. The first oil is expected to be delivered to the refineries in about August. Because the price has been reduced under the new agreement from $3.19 to $2.43 or $2.47, according to quality, this will mean that people going to bowsers to get petrol will not have to pay the substantial increases outlined by various members of the Opposition and by university people. In fact the price of petrol is not expected to rise, because of this new pricing formula and agreement, by more than half a cent per gallon between now and Christmas.

- I wish to ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry the following questions: What was the sum total of devaluation compensation promised to the dairying industry by the Federal Government on the devaluation of the British £Stg1? To what extent has the Government fulfilled its promise? If there is a balance of payment still to be made, how much is it and when does the Government propose to make a further payment of the whole or part of the amount necessary to compensate the industry?
- If the Senate will bear with me for a moment, I think I have some information on this matter. The amount of compensation paid to the Australian Dairy Produce Board and the

speech.para: Queensland Butter Board for immediate loss was $2. 6m. Out of an estimated $9.1m to be paid with respect to 1967-68 the sum of $4.4m has been paid. In December 1968 it was announced that compensation would be paid with respect to the 1968-69 production. It was estimated that $17.4m would then be payable by way of compensation. The total amount of devaluation compensation to the dairying industry is estimated to be S29m.

talk.start.para: - 1 rise to order. I draw your attention, Mr Pesident, to the fact that a question similar to the one just asked is on notice. I refer to question No. 918.
- An answer has been given. The honourable senator is a little late in taking 'his point.

- I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In the light of the grave concern expressed by the President of the New South Wales Branch of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union at the effect on employment opportunities in the industry of the proposed closure of slaughtering facilities at the Canberra Abattoir, can the Minister indicate whether a statement will be made on the future of this establishment before the Senate rises on Thursday?
- I think that this question should more properly be directed to the Minister for the Interior. I shall see that it is so directed.

- My question is directed to the Minister for Customs and Excise. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in today's Brisbane Press of the arrival in Brisbane of the first ship under the new customs rule relating to oral declarations by incoming passengers? Will the Minister inform the Senate whether any unnecessary delay was caused to passengers in clearing customs in this case? Will the Minister do all he can to see that passengers are cleared in the shortest possible time, as many of these people are tourists from overseas and the tourist industry is of great importance to Queensland?

- The Department of Customs and Excise has now introduced the principle of oral declarations by overseas visitors who come here by ship. The new system is similar to that which has been operating for over 12 months with respect to people travelling to Australia by air, and it has been introduced because of the great success achieved by this system in connection with overseas visitors who arrive by air. At the moment the system is going through a trial period. At a later date I shall be pleased to report upon the success or otherwise of the system of oral declarations by people travelling to this country by ship.

talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the final survey of smoking attitudes yet been received from the National Health and Medical Research Council? If so, when will it be made available? If it has not yet been received, what is delaying the Council?

- "Hie Smoking Sub-committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council met on 29th January, and again in February of this year. This Sub-Committee's survey of smoking attitudes will be referred to the Medical Statistics Committee, which will meet on 2nd April 1969, and to the Public Health Advisory Committee which meets on 1 2th and 13th May. Then these Committees will submit a recommendation to the National Health and Medical Research Council which will meet on 15th and 1 6th May. After these meetings it is expected that an announcement will be made concerning smoking attitudes.

- 1 address a question to the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities, lt relates to a question I asked him earlier this session concerning the possible development of Central Australia to attract tourists to that part of the country. ls it a fact that, since I asked my question, the Minister has taken the trouble to visit Central Australia himself? Will he give some idea of his impression as to whether it is possible lo develop a train of stations to encourage tourists to go there? Did he. while he was in Central Australia, announce details of an expert team to study various areas and plan the development of that part of the country?

- It is a fact that within the last 3 weeks 1 have visited Alice Springs and the area of Ayers Rock and Mount Olga. My visit there confirmed the view that it is a unique area of Australia which has a fascinating interest for overseas tourists. At one resort I was informed that last year there had been bookings for 600 American tourists and that this year there were already bookings for 1,000 tourists. I announced during my visit there, as I had previously announced in the Senate, that the Australian Tourist Commission has engaged experts to make an assessment of the area and expects the co-operation of the Northern Territory Reserve Board in having the area around Mount Olga and Ayers Rock assessed conjointly by the same team. I expect that assessment to be made within the next 3 or 4 months.

- 1 address a question to the Minister for Customs and Excise. I remind him that he said yesterday that in the last 12 months the payment of a large amount of money as customs duty had been evaded and that the officers concerned had been charged. Does the Minister now say that the officers have not been charged but have been reprimanded only? Were they reprimanded only because of the latest interpretation of Public Service practice that if they were charged and found guilty they could tender their resignations and escape scot free from any punishment? What was the amount of customs duly evaded in respect of cigarettes and tobacco? What legal proceedings are in fact being taken and against whom? Finally, has any investigation been made to ascertain how deep these rackets are running within the Department of Customs and Excise?

- I mentioned in the course of my speech that the officers concerned had been charged and disciplined for negligence. In relation to the other part of the honourable senator's question, 1 ask him to place that on notice.

- Mr President,some time ago 1 addressed to the Minister for External Affairs a question which 1 believe would have been more appropriately addressed to the Minister for External Territories. Have I your permission to address the question to the appropriate Minister?
- Yes.

- So that the Minister may be reminded of the question, I restate it in these terms: What reaction, if any, has been evidenced in New Guinea following the United Nations mission calling for a vote under United Nations supervision for determination of a date for New Guinea's independence?

- lt will be recalled that in December the United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution calling for a target date and for elections in New Guinea. The voting was 72 for and 19 against. In answer to the honourable senator's question 1 am happy to inform him that the House of Assembly in New Guinea has passed this resolution:

quote.para: That this House rejects as an unwarranted insult to its members, the Administration and the people of this Territory the resolution passed by the United Nations General Assembly calling for elections under United Nations supervision.

speech.para: The House of Assembly went on in its resolution to state that it considered that the United Nations General Assembly's resolution was utterly unjustified by the facts and could tend to undermine the confidence that the Territory would have in the continued goodwill expected from the United Nations.

talk.start.para: - 1 direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. I refer to the sum of $22,906 in Commonwealth subsidy paid to the Queensland company Artesian Basin Oil Pty Ltd. Is the Minister aware that this money was used to upgrade the value of the lease held by the company to enable it to sell its interest to Exoil (NL) at a great profit? Is the Minister also aware that Mr Bjelke-Petersen was the prime mover in the share transactions? What steps will the Minister's Department take to prevent misuse of oil subsidy money?

- 1 am fully aware that the Commonwealth Government's policy in relation to oil exploration has achieved wonderful and staggering results inasmuch as we hope to be getting in the very near future at least 70% of Australia's oil requirements from our own companies drilling for oil. We will have it refined in Australia by companies established in Australia. Our petrol will flow through petrol bowsers to our motorists at reasonable prices. As to the honourable senator's charges against a State Premier and his question about an amount of $22,906, I ask him to place the question on notice and I will get an answer from the Minister for National Development.

- I address my question to the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities. I was very interested to hear the Minister's recent reply which stated that a team of experts for inspection of the Alice Springs area is envisaged. Has the Minister considered the desirability and practicability of causing the team of experts to examine the areas in the north of South Australia, in the Flinders Range, and even the areas containing the opal mining centres of South Australia at Coober Pedy and Andamooka, as places with unique outback attraction for tourists from overseas?

- It is considered possible that the areas to which Senator Laught has referred could be embraced within the proposed study; that is, the area of the Flinders Range and the northern area in which Coober Pedy is located. Whether that extension of the ambit of the assessment is made will depend primarily upon the South Australian Government's wishes in the matter. I have reason to believe that this matter has not escaped its consideration.

- Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for National Development been drawn to an article in the Melbourne 'Sun' of 16th August 1967 which contains a statement by Sir Henry Bolte on the building of the Buffalo Dam? Sir Henry is quoted as saying that Victoria is not likely to give away its water to someone else and would no! consider sharing its water from the new

speech.para: Buffalo Dam unless the River Murray Commission made a very attractive offer. Does the Minister not believe that this makes nonsense of the alleged fight being waged for South Australia to receive an extra .25 million acre feet of water a year through the building of a dam at Dartmouth instead of at Chowilla?

talk.start.para: - No doubt Sir Henry Bolte was endeavouring to look after Victoria. I say to the honourable senator that all the questions he is directing to me as the Minister representing the Minister for National Development in relation to the Chowilla scheme tend to make me believe that Opposition senators are anxious to deprive the people of South Australia of the amount of water the honourable senator has mentioned, namely, about .25 million acre feet a year.

- Will the Leader of the Government in the Senate inform the House whether he and/or the Government approve the allocation of oil search subsidies to companies which obviously have been formed for the purpose of speculation? ls the Minister satisfied beyond all doubt that subsidy paid to Artesian Basin Oil Co. Pty Ltd was not in fact used as a lever to bolster the price of shares in that company?

- I think the question might more property have been directed to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. Therefore 1 suggest that it go on notice, directed to the Minister for National Development.

- I address my question to the Minister for Supply. On Thursday, 27th February, I asked him a question relating to the modification of Mirage aircraft at Avalon, in Victoria. Did he in his reply indicate that the work would be completed in the shortest possible time? I ask him whether he stated also: lt should be appreciated that this work is an integral part of the operational capacity of the RAAF and therefore cannot be spoken of in detail.

speech.para: I accepted that statement in good faith as the implication was that further detailed information was classified. I ask him further whether the honourable member for Kennedy last night in another place quoted the Minister for Supply as replying to me in the following words:

quote.para: The work will be completed in the shortest possible time. . .In fact the work is ready in hand and will be completed by 1971.

speech.para: As that information was not supplied to me by the Minister, has he given information on this matter to the honourable member for Kennedy which he was not prepared to disclose to me in this chamber?

talk.start.para: - I should like to see what was said in the other place, so I shall have a look in Hansard at the end of question time. There is no doubt that what 1 said to the honourable senator is recorded in Hansard but without having a quick look at it I think I said words to the effect that the work would be carried out in the shortest possible time having regard to RAAF requirements. As far as I can recall I have had no communication with the honourable member for Kennedy and 1 will have to make inquiries later to find out what this is all about.

speech.para: Later:

talk.start.para: - I have had a look at the Hansard record, which Senator Poyser was kind enough to send to me. Quite clearly there is a misquotation of the answer I gave the honourable senator. The honourable member purports to quote what 1 said in this place and, as the honourable senator has pointed out, I did not say that. As far as I can remember I did not say anything about 1971.

- A Although I address my question to the Minister for Repatriation it concerns also the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service. It relates to changes in the Defence (Re-establishment) Act last year when provision was made for national servicemen to extend their period of service by 3 months. As the result of that, however, they lose the right to re-establishment benefits, including vocational training. Since this mistake became evident has any administrative action been taken to provide these benefits to servicemen in that category? If legislation is pending, when is it likely to be introduced?

- It is true, as the honourable senator has said, that national servicemen were given a period of 3 months to apply for re-establishment benefits. Unfortunately in one sense, some of the national servicemen decided to re-enlist. Apparently in doing so they did not realise that they were cutting themselves adrift from the re-establishment benefits. We have been assured by the Army now that in cases of re-enlistment these chaps are told of the position which confronts them. The matter has been examined by a committee which has been set up and which is chaired by an officer of my Department. I have taken up the matter with my ministerial colleagues - the Minister for the Army, the Minister for Labour and National Service and the Treasurer - but as yet we have not arrived at a decision. However the matter is being considered.

- -My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will he ask the Treasurer whether the policy of seeking to raise capital for the Australian Resources Development Bank within Australia only is to be changed in order to encourage investment in the Bank from overseas as well? I am prompted to make this comment because of the remarkable success of the latest issue of transferable certificates of deposit, which demonstrates the confidence of the Australian people-
- Order! You will ask your question, Senator Cotton.
- I asked the question at the beginning. I was explaining why 1 did so.
- I will make inquiries from the Treasurer along the lines mentioned by the honourable senator.

- I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service. In view of the threat of substantial unemployment in the metals industries in Queensland and the subsequent decision of unionists employed in those industries to impose overtime bans, will the Minister influence his colleagues to release foreseeable government contracts to ease the situation and ensure that all contracts, be they for the Government or for private industry, are executed in Australia rather than farmed out to overseas interests?

- I have no doubt that the proper course for me to take is to refer the question to my colleague for consideration, but in doing so let me add that I think that the implication, in the latter part of the honourable senator's question, that overseas interests would be given work to the detriment of Australian interests is without foundation.
- Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate seen today's Sydney 'Daily Mirror' in which there is a report of an interview with the wife of Mr Gerard Charles Hoffmann? It reads:

quote.para: We would welcome the tabling in Parliament of a full transcript of the tribunal proceedings into my husband's conduct. . . .

talk.start.para: - Order! Senator Wheeldon, you are out of order in reading from a newspaper and framing a question on a newspaper article.
- For my guidance, Mr President, would you point out to me the standing order which prevents my doing that?
- It does not m alter about the standing order. You are out of order in reading from the newspaper and in framing a question on it as you go along. Either reframe the question or resume your seat.

- As I am assured that the standing order does not matter, and as you say that I am out of order, I will accept your ruling, Mr President. I ask the Minister whether he has seen a copy of today's Sydney 'Daily Mirror' in which Mrs Mary Anna Hoffmann, wife of Mr Gerard Charles Hoffmann, said:

quote.para: We would welcome the tabling in Parliament of a full transcript of the tribunal proceedings into my husband's conduct in the Public Service.

speech.para: In view of the sympathy which was expressed during last evening's adjournment debate by the Leader of the Government for Mr Hoffmann in his present position, and in view of the statements that have been made by various Government senators that the actions in recent days of the Opposition have in some way embarrassed Mr Hoffmann, will the Government accede to the request of Mr and Mrs Hoffmann as reported in the Sydney 'Daily Mirror' and, for the sake of this couple, agree to table the papers?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the first question is no. As all subsequent questions stem from the first question, I am not in a position to answer the honourable senator. I have not had the opportunity of reading this afternoon's 'Daily Mirror'. Having regard to the type of work that one does in this place, if one can read the newspapers the day after they are published one is doing very well. If the honourable senator likes to put on notice any subsequent questions that he asked on this basis, he is at liberty to do so.

- I ask the Minister representing the Minister for National Development: Is it a fact that oil subsidies are paid on actual results of expenditure by oil prospecting companies or during prospecting operations and not in anticipation of drilling operations?

- The honourable senator is asking me whether or not it is a fact that oil drilling subsidies are paid after the work is done. My recollection of the Act and the administration of it is that a company has to perform and give notice of the reason for performing before it is entitled to the subsidy.

- I ask a very simple question of the Minister for Customs and Excise. Can he tell me to whom did Mr Hoffmann issue advice that a by-law to issue 5,000 pairs of turtle skins had been approved, knowing that this was not true?
- I would like the honourable senator to place that question on notice because there are problems associated with the answer.

- I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. What means will be used to transport water between the Dartmouth Dam and Adelaide? Will this transport be by pipeline? If so, what size pipe is to be used? What is the estimated quantity of water that will be delivered to South Australia each day? If transport is to be by means other than through pipeline, what form will the transport take? If it is to be by open channel, what is the distance to be traversed? How will flow pressure be maintained? What percentage of the water leaving the dam will be lost by evaporation and soil absorption? The Minister was pretty loquacious before; let him answer that.
- As the question requires so much detail to be provided in the answer, I ask the honourable senator to place it on notice.

- I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health a question. Last week, I would inform the Minister, the Minister for Health, Dr Forbes, in another place publicly endorsed demands by Victorian doctors for restriction on the sale of what he called 'bromide relaxant tablets'. My question is: In the public interest, will the Minister spell out and publicise the trade names for what he calls 'bromide relaxant tablets'?
- I recall seeing the comments to which the honourable senator refers. I shall place before the Minister for Health the request of the honourable senator.

- Yesterday the Minister for Works answered a question concerning Aboriginal scholarships in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Education and Science. Will the Minister inform the Senate from which States the nine students for university scholarships came and from which States the thirty students for secretarial and business coll'ege courses came?
- J n answer to the question of the honourable senator, I wish to inform him that I will have to get these details from the office records, and I shall be pleased to do so.

- I ask the Minister for Supply a question. Is it a fact that because of the ability of New Zealand jam makers to purchase sugar at a price much tower than Australian jam manufacturers pay, New Zealand jam makers are able to underquote Australian jam manufacturers for Department of Supply contracts? Have New Zealand jam makers obtained contracts from the Department because of this and, if so, what is the amount involved in these contracts?
- I would need to refer to the Department of Supply to get the facts in relation to the question. I see no reason why I would not be able to get them and have them available tomorrow.

- I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to the statement recently emanating from the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area that there was approximately 50,000 tons of rice husks available for processing and that these rice husks currently were going to waste? Will the Minister ask for the help of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Forest Products lo see whether these rice husks would provide sufficient raw material for a wall board plant in the area?

- I have seen an announcement regarding the disposal of the huge quantity of rice husks as mentioned by the honourable senator. I will convey his request to the Minister. I have seen some of the huge quantity of rice husks in this area. I have the greatest confidence that the CSIRO will come up with a scheme to enable the effective use of this large surplus of rice husks.

- I preface my question to the Minister for Customs and Excise by drawing his attention to the reply that he gave to Senator Cohen yesterday. Referring to the interview between himself and Mr Hoffmann, the Minister stated that Mr Hoffmann came to him to thank him and officers of the Department of Customs and Excise for what they had done. I. ask: What had the Minister and the officers done for Mr Hoffmann, other than charge him with serious breaches of the Public Service Act? Does this action justify thanks?

- I am sorry, but I was interrupted half way through the question. If it is clear, Senator Cavanagh is asking me what did the officers of my Department and I do to help Mr Hoffmann after his resignation had been accepted. I saw Mr Hoffmann on 26th November. In answer to a question from Senator Cohen yesterday, I gave the reasons for the interview. It was to discuss his new life in Sydney, with a new job. He wanted to thank me and the officers of my Department. He did at this interview. The reason for his thanks I will state now. We have to get this quite clear. This is why I hate this persecution attitude of members of the Opposition in trying to belittle Mr Hoffmann. Mr Hoffmann was employed by the Department of Customs and Excise from 1951, 1 think, to 1968, a matter of 17 years. He committed one offence.
- How does the Minister know?
- He was charged for that offence and he lost his job.
- No, he did not. He resigned.

- He lost his job. He was given notice of dismissal and his resignation was accepted before the notice of dismissal became applicable. I ask the honourable senators who are interjecting to let me finish, because we want to get this matter quite clear. Because Mr Hoffmann had made only the one mistake, officers of my Department contacted employment agencies, or an employment agency, and obtained for him a job in Sydney.
- At $9,000 a year.

- I do not know the amount of salary. That is between him and the company for which he is working. A satisfactory job was obtained for him in Sydney. I thought that would be the end of the matter. Because he had obtained this job on the recommendation of the chief officer of the Department, through the Commonwealth employment agency, he thanked the officers and me for the work done for him.

- I direct a question to the Minister for Customs and Excise. Is it a fact that the profits of oil firms operating in Australia have increased sixfold in the past year? If that is correct, can an increase in the price of petrol be justified?

- The price of petrol in Australia is cheaper than that in many other countries. It is interesting to know that in America and Canada the price paid for indigenous crude oil is about $3.50 a barrel. We will be producing crude oil in Australia, and after 17th September 1970 Esso-BHP will be receiving a price of only $2.06 a barrel. The honourable senator asks: Why should that put up the price of petrol? The answer is that come 1.7th September 1970 the price of petrol should be, or will be, the same as it is at the present time if we take into consideration only the Government's oil pricing policy.

- I direct a question to the Minister for Customs and Excise. I do not know whether I heard or interpreted correctly the answer he gave a few minutes ago regarding the reason for Mr Hoffmann's visit to him after Mr Hoffmann's dismissal. If I beard him aright, he said that Mr Hoffmann came back to thank him and the officers of the Department of Customs and Excise for finding him a position with some private firm. All I want to ask the Minister now is: Is it the normal practice of the Minister and/or officers of his Department to find employment for employees who are dismissed or who resign from the Department, or was Mr Hoffmann given special, privileged treatment? If he was, for what reason was Mr Hoffmann given the preferential treatment?

- I did not say that Mr Hoffmann came back. I saw him on only the one occasion. I explained to the Senate the reason why some treatment was given to Mr Hoffmann. Because of the long service that he had given to the Department, the Department, having sympathy for him, endeavoured to get and succeeded in getting him a job that was satisfactory to him.

- Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry been drawn to a recent comment by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, which stated: 'The way to beat failing prices and increasing costs is to improve the quality of the produce sold off the farm'? Will the Minister for Primary Industry ask his Department to obtain from the Victorian Department information on positive suggestions that it has to bring about this position?

- 1 did not sec the announcement made by the Victorian body, as mentioned by Senator Cotton. But I agree that if suggestions could come from the body that made this statement they would be very valuable indeed and a lot of credence would be given to them. The only point is that I am afraid that when we do receive the suggestions they probably will not hold water. However, I will transmit the honourable senator's suggestion to the Minister for Primary Industry.

speech.para: Fill AIRCRAFT

talk.start.para: - Will the Minister representing the Minister for Air tell us what he knows about the latest reported crash of an Fill aircraft in America?

- The Minister for Air made a statement on this matter in another place this afternoon. There has been a crash of an Flit on a training flight. The two pilots ejected. The Minister for Air and his Department are keeping in close contact with the relevant American department in connection with the crash.

Is it a fact that about thirty senior journalists including employees of the Australian Broadcasting Commission have been rejected for appointment to the vacant position of Canberra commentator for the top rated ABC programme 'This Day Tonight'? Will the Postmaster-General ask the ABC to appoint immediately an unbiased political commentator in Canberra and to stop attempting to reduce the status of the programme by having an infrequent Canberra coverage using temporary journalists?

item.para: Is the Prime Minister aware of any parallel action to that taken in relation to the recent acceptance of a resignation by a Government employee when the employee was to be dismissed for serious misconduct arising from his employment?

Is the Prime Minister aware of the fact that apprentices in a Government department have had their indentures cancelled when found guilty of the offence of stealing watermelons, and representations on their behalf have been rejected by the Government?

item.para: I have been informed by the Public Service Board of two other occasions during the last 2 years on which the resignation of an officer, concerning whom a dismissal certificate had been issued, has been accepted.

No. However, I am informed that in 1960 a Technician-in-training in the Postmaster-General's Department, Brisbane, was dismissed from the Public Service from the close of business on 24th February 1960 for convictions, involving the stealing of water melons, and wilfully and unlawfully destroying a window. On 26th October 1959 the trainee had been reprimanded by the Public Service Board in relation to a conviction on 14th September 1959 for the stealing of a chair.

If the honourable senator will provide me with the names of the apprentices to whom he referred I will make further inquiries. (Question No. 919)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for

speech.para: Customs and Excise, upon notice:

item.para: Can the Minister inform the Parliament, if, in the course of the investigation by his Department in relation to the charge against Mr G. C. Hoffmann, it was suspected or, indeed, found to be true that Gerard Charles Hoffmann was acting on the instruction of, or in liaison with, Mr James Francis O'Brien, then an officer of the Department of Trade and Industry?
Did both officers resign as a direct result of the investigation referred to?

item.para: There is no evidence that Mr Hoffmann acted on the instruction of Mr O'Brien. Mr Hoffmann did state to the Department of Customs and Excise that Mr O'Brien had contacted him seeking to expedite a decision on the by-law application for turtle skins.

quote.para: Was any officer of the Department of Customs and Excise involved in the widespread conspiracy to evade customs duties on a great scale, to which the Minister referred publicly last year?

talk.start.para: -I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Department of Customs and Excise has delected several incidents in the last year or more in which there had been a substantial evasion of customs duties. These matters have been referred to at various times in Parliament.

In respect of one of these, where certain companies evaded duty payable on the importation of cigars and cigarettes, a number of officers of the Department were charged and disciplined for negligence. This matter was also referred to in the last Auditor-General's report. (Question No. 922)

quote.para: Did Gerard Charles Hoffmann, in order to arrange the import of turtle skins without payment of duty create a new by-law under the Minister's authority for such illegal importation?

talk.start.para: - I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

talk.start.para: asked the Minis ter for Customs and Excise, upon notice:

quote.para: Bearing in mind the Minister's statement in the Senate on 4th March 1969 that he had received a letter from Mr G. C. Hoffmann, dated 1 1th November 1963. seeking his permission to resign, can the Minister say whether the article first appearing inthe journal 'Incentive' of 11th November 1968, the same date, relating to activities going on within his Department, had been brought to the Minister's notice before it was decided to allow Mr Hoffmann to tender his resignation or before the Minister had interviewed Mr Hoffmann?

talk.start.para: - I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for

speech.para: Customs and Excise, upon notice:

quote.para: Were there any instances, other than for which Mr Hoffmann was charged and found guilty, in which Messrs Hoffmann and O'Brien were involved; if so, what was the total amount of duty avoided?

talk.start.para: - I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question: 1 have been advised by the Department of Customs and Excise that it is not aware of any other instances in which Messrs Hoffmann and O'Brien were involved. (Question No. 932)
asked the Minister for Customs and Excise, upon notice:

quote.para: Did a person employed in Parliament House last November ring the Minister and arrange the interview between Mr Hoffmann and himself?

talk.start.para: - I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: A Mr Cullen, employed by the Parliamentary Leader of the Australian Labor Party, rang my private secretary on approximately 7th November 1968 to arrange an interview between Mr Hoffmann and myself. Mr Cullen was advised by my private secretary that an interview could not be arranged at that stage and he suggested that Mr Hoffmann should sent a letter to me stating his reasonsfor seeking an interview. (Question No. 933)

quote.para: By what amount was Mr G. C. Hoffmann's furlough pay reduced as the result of a determination by the Public Service Board, referred to by the Minister in his reply to Senator McClelland's Question No. 907?

talk.start.para: - I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: Pay equivalent to three-tenths of a month, i.e. $167.25.

talk.start.para: - On 25th February, Senator Cant asked me, as Leader of the Government, the following question:

quote.para: Mas any pressure been brought to bear on the Australian Government by the Government of the United Stales to ratify the Non-Proliferation Treaty before nuclear energy is used to develop a harbour at Cape Keraudren? Has the Government of the United States ratified the NonProliferation Treaty?

speech.para: In the course of my reply, I said that I might want to give a supplementary answer in relation to the present signatories to the Non-Proliferation Treaty.

It requires 43 ratifications, including those of Britain, the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which are the depositary governments for the Treaty, to bring it into effect. Britain is the only depositary government to have deposited its instruments of ratification to date, although the USA and the USSR have signed the Treaty. Ratification procedures are in progress in the United States.
