item.para: Is it a fact that James Francis O'Brien resigned as an officer of the Department of Trade and Industry as a result of certain investigations but was not charged.
Did James Francis O'Brien lose all or any of his furlough entitlement under section SS of the Public Service Act as a result of the investigation carried out into his activities?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Trade and Industry has provided me with the following information:

item.para: At the request of the Secretary of the Department of Trade and Industry, an investigation was conducted by the Commonwealth police in 1968 into certain aspects of the conduct of Mr

speech.para: James Francis O'Brien. Before the investigation was complete, Mr O'Brien resigned. No charge was laid against him.

item.para: The relevant provisions of the Public Service Act are contained in section 73, not in section 55. Under those provisions Mr James Francis O'Brien was paid an amount of $3,846.75 representing payment in lieu of 6 9/10ths months' furlough, 3/10ths of 1 month having been deducted from his maximum entitlement of 7 2/10lhs months. (Question No. 916)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice:

quote.para: If James Francis O'Brien lost all or part of his furlough entitlement as a result of investigations into his activities in the Department of Trade and Industry and in accordance with the provisions of section 55 of the Public Service Act, why was he not charged for the same offences and dismissed in the same way as originally applied to Mr Hoffmann?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Trade and Industry has supplied me with the following information:

quote.para: The situation in relation to Mr O'Brien was that the investigations were incomplete when he resigned. 1 am advised that an officer who has resigned from the Public Service cannot be charged under the Public Service Act. (Question No. 923)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice:

item.para: During November last year, was an officer of the Department of Trade and Industry interrogated for eight hours by Commonwealth police?
Was the interrogation in relation to the officer's employment and was a report from the Commonwealth police made to the Minister?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for and Industry has supplied the following information:

item.para: There was no interrogation during November, but in September Mr James Francis O'Brien was questioned by the Commonwealth police.

The questioning related to certain aspects of this officer's conduct. The Commonwealth police reported to the Secretary of my Department, who is responsible for matters of discipline within the Department.

debateinfo.title: GREAT BARRIER REEF AREA: OIL DRILLING AND MINING

talk.start.para: - I have received from Senator Keeffe an intimation that he desires to move the adjournment of the Senate for the purpose of discussing a matter of urgency, namely:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to give adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted.

speech.para: Is the motion supported? (More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places) -

talk.start.para: - I rise to order, Mr President. 1 address myself to the point of order on the basis that I hope I shall obtain from you the wisdom which you accord to interpreting both the Standing Orders and the practice of the Senate. An urgency motion has been moved and has been supported by honourable senators. The motion is in accordance with and pursuant to standing order 64. I seek your guidance on this matter, Sir, because standing order 125 reads as follows:

quote.para: No Motion or Amendment shall anticipate an Order of the Day or another Motion of which Notice has been given.

speech.para: Standing order 419 states:

quote.para: No Senator shall digress from the subjectmatter of any Question under discussion; nor anticipate the discussion of any subject which appears on the Notice Paper: . . .

speech.para: Obviously that refers to the Senate notice paper. I direct my attention to these two standing orders, which I suggest must be read in conjunction with standing order 64, because the Senate already has this matter under its survey and surveillance. A Senate select committee has been charged by the Senate with the examination of this problem. The matter appears on the notice paper. I suggest, that under the two standing orders I have referred to - I consider they must be read in conjunction with standing order 64 under which Senator Keeffe and his supporters have moved this motion - honourable senators opposite are out of order. 1 suggest that they are canvassing a matter which is before a select committee of the Senate; therefore it should not be debated on the grounds that it is anticipating a matter which at present appears on the notice paper. 1 know there are difficulties associated with this matter. I also address my attention to the 'Australian Senate Practice', third edition, in which the eminent and learned Clerk who sits in front of you, Sir, deals with the problems in which the Senate finds itself involved from time to time. I refer you, Mr President, to chapter 14, page 198 of 'Australian Senate Practice' which is headed 'Motion for Adjournment to Debate Matter of Urgency'. In that chapter the learned Clerk of the Senate properly provides for the instruction of senators matters that arise in relation to a motion for adjournment in order to debate a matter of urgency. For example, I direct attention to the second paragraph on page 198 in which a 1957 case is used as an illustration. The author states:

quote.para: A Senator gave notice to the President of his intention to move the adjournment of the Senate to discuss the effect on Universities of a Bill before the Queensland Parliament which related to the administration of the University of Queensland. The President ... in a private ruling, indicated that the motion, if proposed, would be disallowed because the Commonwealth Government had no administrative responsibility in tha matter.

speech.para: The President went on to refer to 'May*. Then, in the ultimate paragraph of that page - and I quote it because it can be said that perhaps in quoting it I am taking a point against myself - it is stated that the President upheld a point of order that a motion was not in order because it dealt with a matter that was not a Commonwealth responsibility but one for which the Government of Western Australia was responsible. I mention those two paragraphs only so that no honourable senator present can say that I am being anything less than fair. The motion of which Senator Keeffe has given notice gives as its reason:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the-

speech.para: I pause there to direct your attention to the subsequent words that appear in the terms of the motion. They are: the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted.
The passage reads, in full:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance thai oil drilling and mining in the Great Burrier Reef areas will not be permitted.

speech.para: I direct your attention, Mr President, to the fact that the Commonwealth Government does not have jurisdiction over the Great Barrier Reef, even under our Petroleum (SubmergedLands)ActwhichIhave examined. Here I would refer to what the Attorney-General (Mr Bowen) said during the course of his second reading speech when introducing that measure in another place. He said that involved in this was the inability to distinguish what was the area of jurisdiction of the Commonwealth under that measure and what was the area of jurisdiction of the sovereign State of Queensland. I direct attention to the fact that the motion in question here refers to the Great Barrier Reef areas. This is an allembracing designation which concerns a matter in which there is a division of authority as to what is the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government of Australia and therefore the ministerial, responsibility of the Commonwealth.

The second matter is the areas which are the responsibility of the sovereign State of Queensland. Therefore I suggest that, in accordance with the rulings and practice of the Senate, the Parliament has but limited powers to argue as to assurances in relation to, for example, matters that deal with the sovereign rights of the State of Queensland. It was only on 4th March - yesterday - that a similar motion was introduced in another place. As discussion of that matter is now concluded I may refer to it. The debate is reported in full in yesterday's Hansard of another place.

The honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson), a member of the Opposition in another place, launched debate on a matter of urgency in terms substantially the same as those contained in the motion which Senator Keeffe has moved this afternoon. After the honourable member for Dawson had completed his introductory speech the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn) replied, and I seek your permission to quote what he said for your information so that you may advise me on the question that I have raised with relation to the jurisdiction of the Senate in this matter and the propriety of Senator Keeffe's moving of the motion, bearing in mind that it refers to an area that is not specified or designated and where there is a division of authority which is not specified. On page 331 of
Hansard of another place the Minister for National Development is reported as having said:

quote.para: We are concerned that any proposal might lead todamageordesocrationofthismagnificent wonder-

speech.para: Then he goes on to say:

quote.para: But we cannot ignore the fact that it is not easy to determine where our powers lie in this matter. I am told on the best legal advice that any land above low water mark is the property of Queensland.

speech.para: He continues:

quote.para: A tremendous number of islands on the Reef-

speech.para: The word 'Reef comes in here - not Barrier Reef'- are above low water mark and, therefore, are Queensland territory. If we accept that Queensland has authority over an area extending seaward for 3 miles from all its territory it would have authority for 3 miles all around those islands. So it is not simply a matter of the Commonwealth making a decree, as has been suggested by the honourable member for Dawson, and saying to Queenslanders, 'To hell with you'.
The next and pregnant sentence is:

quote.para: We must respect Queensland's authority wherever it exists.

speech.para: So, asI did when opening my remarks, I suggest that the motion in the terms as submitted to the Senate is out of order. Firstly, it seeks to examine the jurisdiction of the sovereign State of Queensland in an area which is not defined; but implicitly it seeks to extend authority over the sovereign State of Queensland. Secondly, there is constitutional propriety involved in this question. Thirdly, 1 suggest that this is a device which is being used for party political purposes and not in the interests of public urgency. Therefore, I suggest that the motion is out of order and should not be accepted.

talk.start.para: - I suggest that the point of order is not well taken. So far as constitutional propriety and other points taken by the honourable senator are concerned, one has only to consider what the Senate did with relation to the appointment of the Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources to understand that this Parliament, and therefore the Senate as part of it, has a legislative interest in all these areas; otherwise we could not have set up that committee. It is one of the particular subject matters of inquiry by this Senate and there is no substance in the objection at all. You might as well say we were not entitled to set up the Select Committee to inquire into any of these matters. At best, the honourable senator says there is some doubt about who owns the areas. These matters are not resolved by doubts.

speech.para: The reality is that apparently the permits have to be approved or consented to at the Federal level. Therefore this Parliament is concerned with the matter, because the Federal Minister can take action to prevent drilling being done. It is clearly a matter of Federal ministerial responsibility. We are concerned with it, and it is being suggested that that responsibility should be exercised in a certain way.
Then the honourable senator says that the motion is contrary to the Standing Orders in that it anticipates something. Standing order 125 reads:

quote.para: No Motion or Amendment shall anticipate an Order of the Day or another Motion of which Notice has been given.

speech.para: No order of the day is being anticipated and there is no other motion of which notice has been given and which this motion anticipates, We therefore suggest that this motion is entirely in order.

A somewhat similar motion was moved on 16th October 1968 dealing with the Gulf of Carpentaria and Great Barrier Reef waters. The matter of definite public importance there, was the failure of the Government to initiate action to police, control and preserve the resources of the waters of the Gulf of Carpentaria and the Great Barrier Reef. I ask you to reject the point of order.

talk.start.para: - Mr President, I seek a ruling on a point of order which, if it is not identical with the point raised by Senator Cormack, concerns an allied matter which would be covered in the objections which he raised. At the outset, by way of desiring to assist you, the point which has been taken by Senator Murphy with regard to a motion in October last year was, 1 put with all respect, irrelevant to the consideration here. That motion was concerned with the waters of the Great Barrier Reef and the Gulf of Carpentaria whereas what is involved in Senator Keeffe's motion are the actual resources of the sea bed. But leaving that aspect aside, it is clear that the Senate has appointed the Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources to examine the provisions of legislation relating to off-shore areas and, in particular, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967.

speech.para: That Select Committee must operate under the provisions of chapter XXI f of the Standing Orders. The Senate having appointed a committee to investigate a matter which comprehends the substance of what Senator Keeffe raises by his motion of urgency, it appears to me that problems arise, not only for the Senate but also for the senators who are members of that Select Committee. Standing order 308 in chapter XXII states:

quote.para: The evidence taken by any Select Committee of the Senate and documents presented to such Committee, which have not been reported to the Senate, shall not be disclosed or published by any member of such Committee, or by any other person.

talk.start.para: - ls Senator Keeffe a member of the Committee?
- He is certainly a member of the Committee, and there are seven other senators who, with Senator Keeffe, constitute the membership of that Committee.
- Mr President, I rise to order. Senator Greenwood is casting aspersions on what I am going to say. 1 think he is entirely wrong in this attitude and should not pursue this line of argument.
- The point of order is not upheld.

- I do hot desire to anticipate what Senator Keeffe will say; to a certain extent that would be beyond me. However, it is apparent that the work of the Committee and the provisions of the legislation which the Committee is investigating comprehend what are the relative powers of the Commonwealth and what are the powers of the State with regard to the Great Barrier Reef area. Looking at the terms of the urgency motion which Senator Keeffe has raised, it is quite obvious that questions of power must arise. He stales in the terms of the motion that he has proposed:

item.para: . the failure ot the Government io give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted.

speech.para: I do not know what Senator Keeffe is going to say. It may be difficult to forecast, in any event, what he would say as to the words 'adequate assurance'. It is clear, nevertheless, that one reasonable interpretation of those words would be as to the power of the Federal Government or the power of a State government to take the necessary steps. Therefore I suggest that one attack which is to be made is on the sufficiency of Commonwealth powers. That was one of the principal matters aired in this chamber as justification for the appointment of the Senate Select Committee. Accordingly, as I said earlier, there is comprehended within the terms of reference of the Select Committee the very matter which this motion contemplates. It is a matter of public knowledge, and not a disclosure of committee affairs, that the Committee has been to the Great Barrier Reef area for the express purpose of hearing submissions and, in due course, considering them. Therefore it becomes a matter of what is the limit upon the Senators and what constraint should be exercised by the Senate in the light of standing order 308. lt would be very difficult for honourable senators to speak on matters in this field without offending the Standing Orders. That is one point.

A second point is that the Senate ought to recognise the difficulty into which it puts its members. Furthermore, having appointed a select committee, the Senate ought to consider whether in those circumstances the honourable senator should embark upon a discussion when it has already given to the Select Committee the obligation of making a major consideration of these matters. I have entered this discussion because I sense that there is here a very real problem. I do not know whether this matter is expressly covered by the Standing Orders, but I certainly ask for your ruling upon it, Mr President. It appears from the Standing Orders that the Committee may report at any stage, or it may report when it has completed its deliberations. If it reports when it has finished its deliberations then, according to standing order 317 the consideration of that report must be by specific motion, of which notice must be given in the usual manner. That would suggest, I submit, that if the report of the Committee were before the Senate it could not be discussed in this way. Therefore I ask whether it is proper for the Senate to discuss matters which are within the terms of reference of the

Select Committee, prior to the Select Committee reporting. Obviously there is embarrassment. 1 suggest that it is proper for the Senate to be concerned with the matters 1 have canvassed, both as to the position of individual senators and the Senate itself. I support the point of order because there is, to my mind, a problem which arises. I ask for your ruling.

talk.start.para: - Is the honourable senator asking for my ruling now?

- 1 understood that Senator Cormack had raised a point of order and had asked for a ruling. I am likewise seeking a ruling on substantially the same matter but raising, as they appear to me, different considerations.
- Is the honourable senator supporting the point of order?
- Yes.

- It was not until the last moment when Senator Greenwood was pressed to define his attitude that we understood him to be supporting Senator Cormack's point of order. He seemed to have half a foot in Senator Cormack's camp and to move into some esoteric area of his own in order to put a submission which was not based on any of the standing orders. I respectfully suggest to you, Mr President, that whether or not it is the same point of order as Senator Cormack raised, you should overrule it. Senator Cormack has invited you to shut out the Senate from debating the matter of urgency, namely, the failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted. Senator Keeffe's notice of motion complies entirely with standing order 64 which deals with motions for adjournment to debate matters of urgency. The only way in which it can be excluded from consideration is if it falls within the terms of standing order 125 which reads, simply:

quote.para: No Motion or Amendment shall anticipate an Order of the Day or another Motion of which Notice has been given.

speech.para: One would have thought that Senator Cormack would have a very difficult job persuading you and the Senate that this motion was anticipating an order of the day because he has not indicated which order of the day it could possibly affect, nor has he referred us to another motion of which notice has been given. What is really being said is that we have a Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources and legislation relating thereto. He has suggested that these are wide terms of reference which might cover some of the matters which may be canvassed in this debate and, therefore, for some extraordinary reason, the Senate is precluded from debating these questions.

That is an extraordinary proposition if it is to be upheld because it means that one can effectively gag the Senate by appointing a select committee. If you uphold the objection it means that anything that falls within the terms of reference of that committee is ipso facto shut out from the consideration of the Senate. I am sure that you would lean against any such construction of the Standing Orders if, indeed, such a construction were open to you.

The plain fact is that the subject matter of this motion involves the Federal Government. It calls into question the failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef area will not be permitted. It is clear that the Federal Government has power to decline to give the permission that is involved in the motion. We are asking the Minister to take a serious view of his responsibilities and to make it plain that such oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef area will not be permitted, because it is a matter within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: - lt is not.

- You may say that is debatable as a matter of law. There may be another point of view that can be put. I do not know what it is at the moment, but I am perfectly clear in my mind, and I respectfully suggest that honourable senators should be clear in their minds, that this is pre-eminently a matter than can be discussed in the Federal Parliament. There is not a tittle of substance in the point of order because no foundation has been laid upon which it could succeed. There is not an order of the day. There is not a notice of motion with which this would interfere, and to ask you, Sir, to fall back upon some inherent jurisdiction of some esoteric illdefined character to say that the Senate should not debate this motion would be assuming a responsibility that is entirely beyond the powers of the President of the Senate. 1 suggest that we should not waste time on this discussion, that the point of order is completely without substance and that you should rule so at the earliest possible moment.

- Mr President, I wish to support the point of order raised by Senator Cormack. I do so partly on the ground of jurisdiction. Until Federation there was considerable doubt about the location of Queensland's maritime boundaries. As recently as I 10th June 1925 - that is, considerably after Federation - Royal Letters Patent were issued from the United Kingdom defining the boundaries of the sovereign State of Queensland. The relevant passage states:

quote.para: The maritime boundary ot Queeusland is the coastline from Point Danger to the 138th meridian in the Gulf of Carpentaria together with all island* within the outer edge of the Barrier Reef and within a line drawn from the north-west point of the Reef to the 138th meridian.

speech.para: That quotation is taken from the book Triumph in the Tropics' by Cilento and Lack, lt is authoritative and I submit that the Government of the sovereign State of Queensland has complete jurisdiction over the Great Barrier Reef and all the islands within the outer edge of the Great Barrier Reef. I support the point of order.

talk.start.para: - Mr President, in all the circumstances 1 am prepared to accept that there is sufficient ministerial responsibility in the matter for the discussion to proceed.

- I consider the motion to be in order. There appears to be some ministerial responsibility as evidenced by the statement of the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Scott). As to the Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources, I think the only limitation should be that the proceedings of the Committee should not bc referred to until it has reported to the Senate. Senator Keeffe, you may proceed.
- I move, pursuant to standing order 64:

quote.para: That the Senate, at its rising, adjourn till tomorrow at 11.15 a.m., for the purpose of debating a matter of urgency, namely:
The failure of the Government to give adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted.

speech.para: I regret that an argument about Standing Orders has taken place and that a challenge was offered in respect of the subject matter of this debate. I regret in particular the inferences drawn by Senator Greenwood, a Liberal senator from Victoria, who implied that I proposed to disclose confidential matters associated with a Senate select committee.

talk.start.para: - 1 rise to a point of order. Standing order 64 (2.) states:

quote.para: In speaking to such motion, the mover and the Minister first speaking shall not exceed thirty minutes each, and any other Senator or the mover in reply shall not exceed IS minutes, and every Senator shall confine himself to the one subject in respect to which the Motion has been made.

speech.para: In accordance with that standing order, on this occasion Senator Keeffe or any other honourable senator shall1 speak only in respect of the failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted. Senator Keeffe is not permitted to launch attacks against honourable senators on this side of the chamber.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bull) - Senator Keeffe, would you please keep to the terms of the subject as you have submitted it to the Senate.

talk.start.para: - 1 bow to you ruling, Sir. I. feel that I was quite justified in making the statement, but I shall temper my remarks in accordance with your ruling. It is not my intention at any stage of this debate to disclose any confidential information that has come into my possession as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Off-Shore Petroleum Resources. However, matters which have been raised in publ'ic session of the Committee have been published in many sections of the Press. I suggest that these are public matters and that in referring to them I will not breach any confidence gained in any discussions that have taken place inside the Committee or with witnesses appearing before the Committee.

speech.para: There is one matter that I think should be cleared up now and placed permanently on the record. I suggest that on a previous occasion when we discussed the Gulf of Carpentaria and the Great Barrier Reef in the Senate, at least a gentleman's agreement was reached between honourable senators opposite and Opposition senators who are members of the Committee, that if we followed the general course of action that I have said I will follow, there would be no problem. As time is limited I wish to proceed now with the argument as outlined in the motion.

The Great Barrier Reef is not a parochial issue, lt is not a subject that concerns only a limited number of people in this country. It is a national asset, or indeed an international asset, and ought to be treated as such. In these circumstances I hope that honourable senators opposite appreciate that this is not a joking matter. The Great Barrier Reef stretches for about 1,200 miles down the coastline of Queensland. It is basically, and perhaps most importantly, a tourist attraction. From time to time the Minister in charge of Tourist Activities (Senator Wright) distributes reports stating that a very large number of visitors to Australia from overseas make a point of seeing the Reef, or at least some of its attractions. The area is rich in fishing resources. I refer not only to the types of fish to be seen in small aquariums but also to the fish that are caught for food in many countries. The Reef acts as a protection against tides and cyclonic disturbances. If the Reef were interfered with to a large degree, one theory that operates holds, a major effect on tides would follow. If the Reef were permanently damaged over a large section, not one surf port on the coast of Queensland would be able to stand up to heavy weather and heavy seas. lt is not necessary to create artificial damage to the Reef, because it has many natural enemies. In the past cyclones have created damage that now, many years later, is still in the process of repair. There is a common misconception as to whether the Reef is dead or living. No accurate survey has been carried out, but estimates of the amount of living coral have varied from 60% to 80% of the total area. In some parts of the Reef, particularly at its northern end, the Crown of Thorns starfish has caused tremendous damage. Currently surveys are being made to discover an agent to control this starfish.

The damage that can be caused by silt is apparent in the Townsville area. In the Cleveland Bay area in days gone by there were a number of small reefs which were alive, but unfortunately most of them now are dead or have disintegrated and have disappeared. The theory expounded by experts on many occasions, and which has not been contradicted, is that this has been caused by silt coming out of the Townsville Harbour. No tests have been carried out in Australia into the effect of oil or any other hydrocarbon type of mineral on living coral.

talk.start.para: - Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to rule whether Senator Keeffe is breaching standing order 308.

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT - No. The President gave a ruling on that matter earlier.

talk.start.para: - Thank you, Sir. The Opposition calls for a series of tests extending over a lengthy period. Until that is done is there anyone in this chamber - I doubt whether anyone in Australia can - who can tell us authoritatively whether the Reef will be damaged by an oil blowout or by an escape from gas wells? Marine life in the vicinity of the Reef depends on the minute creatures of the sea, on things smaller than themselves such as plankton, seagrass and seaweeds. It would be reasonable to assume that an escape of oil directly or indirectly would lake great toll of the type of life on which the larger marine creatures feed.

speech.para: I must refer in a way which I hope will not be offensive to Government members to the joint agreement entered into by the Commonwealth and the States. I am not breaching any confidence of the Off-Shore Petroleum Committee in doing so. In this chamber I and members of the Opposition opposed the legislation as it stood when it was before us on the ground that we felt there was insufficient protection for the Barrier Reef. It is true that a Committee has been set up but 1 cannot make any reference to its findings or deliberations at this stage, nor can I properly do so until its report has been presented.

talk.start.para: - Nor to the evidence before the Committee. That is the point.

- 1 will make my decisions with the assistance of Mr Acting Deputy President and Senator Greenwood might prefer to remain quiet. When the legislation was before the Queensland Parliament that was one point uppermost in the minds not only of members of the official Opposition, the Labor Party, but of other members of the Parliament as well. They were particularly keen and anxious to see that the Barrier Reef was protected. It is significant that the Minister has said outside the chamber, as he did inside the chamber on that occasion, that there was nothing to fear. Probably I could quote a facetious statement he made to the State Legislative Assembly but I do not think it would be the proper thing to do. He said that he would be personally responsible to see that no damage was caused to the Reef or the areas continguous to the Reef. lt is well known, and has been mentioned in this chamber this afternoon, that yesterday in another place there was a debate on this subject. 1 am not satisfied with what the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn) had to say. I am not attacking the Minister. He has to speak in accordance with the policy of the Government. Today some sections of the Press indicated that certain assurances had been given that there would be no drilling in the Reef area. I should like to quote very quickly three or four statements. To me, sufficient assurances have not been given that proper precautions have been taken or that there will be any blocking of exploration or drilling permits on the Reef or in the immediate area of the Reef, and I hope that the Minister who in this place represents the Minister for National Development will convey my sentiments to his colleague. The Minister for National Development said that he agreed entirely with the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) who said that we would have to be very careful in respect of future permits for oil exploration. That would be construed as being a sympathetic statement. Referring to the Queensland Minister for Mines, who was the Designated Authority under the joint legislation and who in this case will have to wear two hats when carrying out his duties, the Minister said:

quote.para: This is the man who, in consultation and cooperation with the Commonwealth Government, is seeing that the Reef is not despoiled.

speech.para: I do not want to use rude words but this is not strictly in accordance with facts. Then he said:

quote.para: The Commonwealth is having discussions with Queensland about searching off-shore for other than oil.

speech.para: Later the Minister for National Development went on to say-
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENTOrder! Senator Keeffe, you must not read place yesterday in another place.

talk.start.para: - If I cannot quote statements that he made a lot of this debate loses its sense completely. May I do so without reading from the report?

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENTYes.

talk.start.para: - The Minister said that three exploratory wells had been drilled but none of them was within 20 miles of the Great Barrier Reef. That is not good enough because it has been proved by the explosions that took place in the Santa Barbara area on one occasion, and on another occasion by oil slicks which drifted many miles with the tides and currents, that damage can be done to the Reef. That is exactly the kind of thing which will take place if there is an accidental spillage from a well or from a pipe in the Barrier Reef area. In the Brisbane daily newspaper, the Courier Mail', on Friday, 13th September 1968, the following report appears:

quote.para: The Premier (Mr Bjelke-Petersen)-

speech.para: Now a well-known name in the oil industry - gave a strong assurance yesterday that the State Government would protect the Great Barrier Reef against exploitation. He said that no mining industry based on harvesting dead coral was permitted on the Reef.

He has made similar statements, many of which he has based on the surveys carried out by Dr Harry Ladd, an American marine biologist, but as I develop my argument I shall prove that this also is not sufficient assurance that the assets of the Reef will be protected or that the Premier intends to protect them.

In addition to the damage that J have mentioned earlier, foreign fishing vessels have played a fairly large part in activities particularly on the northern end of the Reef. As my colleague in another place, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Fulton) could tell you, many Chinese, Japanese and other foreign vessels for a long time have been taking away meat from the giant clams. Of course, once the meat is removed the clam dies. This could upset the ecological balance of all marine life on the Reef. Not enough is known about this. Those people who are scientifically or academically qualified to tell us say that we should not touch the Reef until a suitable period has been spent in carrying out a proper physical and scientific survey.

talk.start.para: - Why did Labor give permits to mine the Reef?
- Senator Webster of the Country Party who is interjecting might like to be recruited as a labourer to remove some of the crown of thorns fish. If this survey were carried out-
-I think I made a valid comment.

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT - Order!

talk.start.para: - I think I can get over the childish voices, Sir. If this survey were carried out we would be able to form a proper assessment of whether this kind of exploitation or exploration should take place. I think that it is fairly commonly known that apart from some investigation carried out at the southern end of the Great Barrier Reef, in the Heron Island area, there are no other scientific stations of any sort of a permanent nature anywhere along the length of the Reef - a total distance of 1,200 miles.
- Heron Island is not part of the Great Barrier Reef.

- I did not say that it was part of the Great Barrier Reef. If Senator Wood had listened to me he would have heard that. He ought to know where Heron Island is. I said 'at the southern end of the Reef in the Heron Island area'. If that is not clear enough for the honourable senator, I will write a letter to him about it next week.

speech.para: May I make further quotations as to the depredation that has been caused by the movement of foreign fishing 'boats into the area. I refer honourable senators to the issue of the 'Courier Mail' of 23rd July 1968. I will have time to quote the headlines only. The article is headed:

quote.para: Second Chinese Boat Seen Inside Limits.
Pirates' protest expected.
Diplomatic repercussions are expected to follow the interception of two Nationalist Chinese fishing boats inside the 12 mile limit off the Queensland coast.

speech.para: It is now history that a great argument developed. Once before I have produced here a map to show that the Barrier Reef does come into this area. It is looked upon as a lucrative fishing field. It is clearly shown on this map.

To substantiate further the arguments that I have been developing, I want to quote from the American magazine 'Time' of 14th February 1969, only 2 weeks or 3 weeks ago. Before doing so, may I say that we received all sorts of assurances, and some of the overseas news items were slanted suitably, to prove to us that no great damage was being caused in Santa Barbara. 'Time' has been looked upon as a reliable magazine even by some members of the Liberal Party. It has this to say:

quote.para: The huge bubble of oil and natural gas boiling up from beneath the surface of Santa Barbara Channel at a rate of almost 1,000 gallons an hour spilled across the blue water for 11 days. It finally coated an area of at least 400 square miles and fouled 40 miles of incomparable beach front with acrid, tarlike slime. 'Time' Correspondent Robert Anson, flying over the despoiled sea, found the fumes noxious at 1,000 feet.

speech.para: A little further on, the article refers to similar tragedies that have taken taken place. It refers to the breakup off Baja, California of the tanker 'Tampico':

item.para: . which dumped 59,000 barrels of diesel oil into the Pacific and 'utterly impoverished animal life' in the area for 5 years.

speech.para: I suggest, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if this type of catastrophe takes place within the Great Barrier Reef area the Reef will be spoiled for a much longer period. If such pollution killed off the top of the Reef over a fairly lengthy area - places like the coast east of Ingham, the Townsville area, the Halifax area, particularly the Lucinda Point bulk storage area, possibly the Cairns area and Mission Beach and the other delightful beaches that we have along the Queensland coast - the area of the Reef involved would be ruined by the high tides and the heavy seas experienced there. The theory has been expounded by people with scientific knowledge. This is what they believe. With no evidence to the contrary, I am prepared to believe it.

I refer to the 'Torrey Canyon' incident. That ship spilt 100,000 tons of crude oil into the English Channel. We are told that 90% of the animal loss was caused by the detergents used to clean up the oil. No real survey has been conducted to inform us whether or not the chemicals used in cleaning up the mess had any serious effects. However this information will come forth in due time. The situation at Santa Barbara is even worse than that. Direct blame is placed on the oil companies. One oil company in particular is named in this article in Time' because it did not exercise proper supervision. One of the State officials asked the then Secretary of the Interior, Stewart Udall, for an extension of the buffer area in this locality of something like 2 miles. Such an area would be completely useless off the Queensland coast with its heavy seas and high tides, even for the protection of the Reef. In Santa Barbara, when an extension was sought, it was not granted. But this is the comment. Santa Barbara County supervisor George Clyde said:

quote.para: Always, Interior and oil officials led us to believe we had nothing to fear.

speech.para: This is what is happening in Australia now. We are told by the representatives of the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government that we have nothing to fear. The oil companies say exactly the same thing, except that they are a little more vocal because they are the people who stand to make the greatest profit. The Time' magazine report continues:

quote.para: The Government, of course, profited by the drilling; last year it made $1.6 billion in rentals, royalties and bonus payments from the Santa Barbara concession. The block that included the leaky Union well was good for $6 1.4m in bonus revenues to the Federal Government.

speech.para: The next statement from 'Time' refers to the oil company responsible for the permit in this area:

quote.para: While known in southern California as 'the gogo company', Union also has picked up something of a reputation as a polluter. Only 2 weeks ago. the company was accused of dumping 1,500 barrels of crude, into the Santa Ana River after a mud slide broke a pipeline. Twice in 1967, the company was brought up on violations of California fish and game statutes for polluting Los Angeles harbour. Indeed, its competitors complain that Union is giving the industry a bad name.

speech.para: Of course, when this problem blew up, its competitors decided to get behind Union for the sake of mutual protection.

I am charging the Commonwealth Government with responsibility in this matter. I think that the onus must come back to the Commonwealth Government because the Queensland Government is not prepared to take the responsibility. The Queensland Government will make every cent that it can out of royalties from oil. Because the Great Barrier Reef is a national asset, I believe that onus is on the Commonwealth Government to give a complete assurance - much better than that which was given by the Minister for National Development in another place approximately 24 hours ago - which will convince all Australians and all Queenslanders in particular that the Commonwealth Government means what it says. The statement outlined by the Minister for National Development yesterday does not appear to convey that impression. If any doubt exists about the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth and State Governments, this doubt ought to be the matter of some sort of emergency discussion so that this question can be resolved satisfactorily.

I wish to make one or two more points and that will conclude my contribution to the debate. I feel that, so far as Queensland is concerned, we have very little chance of overcoming the problems to which I have referred. The Queensland Premier and the Minister for Mines, Main Roads and Electricity on numerous occasions have given this assurance but have not backed it up with anything. There is no legislation to back it up at all. The Minister for Mines, Main Roads and Electricity has said publicly on several occasions that licences or exploration permits will be granted for the Great Barrier Reef area, but only after conditions have been decided. This would take many months. If honourable senators want my authority for that statement they may refer to the 'Queensland Mines Magazine' of January 1969 where this statement was made originally. Perhaps we will find out yet. May I say this also: In his statement the Minister for National Development said that no more permits in certain circumstances will be granted. It might be advisable for a proper investigation to be carried out. Such an investigation might indicate that there is no more reef for which to issue permits and that that has not been made public yet. Because it has not been made public, it creates a further area about which one must be worried.

As I said a few minutes ago, the Queensland Minister clearly indicated that a statement on the successful tenderers for the Reef area would not be made for a long period of time. Under pressure - I leave honourable senators to judge whether from his own Government or from interested oil companies - he said that the announcement would be made in March. For the benefit of those honourable senators who think that I may be going close to the bone in regard to the Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources, 1 point out that these are all public statements appearing in Queensland newspapers and other newspapers in this country. I repeat that the Queensland Minister said that he would make the announcement in March. Then he got down to the day. He said that it would be made on 1st March. Today is 5th March, and the announcement has not yet been made.

Perhaps I should refer to the Queensland Premier here. 1 believe that it is appropriate to do so because he also has been vocal in statements that the Reef area would be protected. Those honourable senators who read the newspapers will know that at the moment the Queensland Premier is in serious difficulties in regard to his holdings in oil companies. It is more than a rumour that one of the reasons why the successful tenderers have not been announced is that the Premier is associated with one of the consortiums seeking to take out leases of Barrier Reef areas.

talk.start.para: - Who told the honourable senator that?
- This is a shocking state of affairs.
- Where is the honourable senator's evidence?

- If Senator Maunsell from the Country Party can understand the prospectus of an oil company, I suggest that he study it tonight. This is what is likely to happen, and this is why no decision has been taken and no firm announcement has been made in relation to the allocation of the permits, and, worst of all, why no firm decision has been taken on whether the Reef is to be protected. When I find that a State government is prepared to involve itself in things of this nature, I despair of the future. That is one of the reasons why we have decided to raise this matter and to make this appeal to the Commonwealth Government to be powerful and strong enough to take the initiative in protecting this natural asset. Honourable senators who are supporting me will develop other points. I am certain that they will cover adequately those details which time has precluded me from including in my contribution to the debate.

- I think I will be excused for referring to the fact that in speaking in this debate I am placed in a more difficult situation than perhaps any other senator apart from the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Scott), who represents the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn). 1 am the chairman of a committee appointed by the Senate to investigate and in due course to report on the off-shore petroleum legislation under very extensive terms of reference to which I will refer later. I am extremely concerned that in no sense will I, as chairman of that committee, breach the rules of the Senate or the secrecy of the proceedings of the committee. This is a problem that will confront all of us who are members of the committee appointed by the Senate when we talk about this matter. I was conscious that Senator Keeffe was labouring under this difficulty. I ask honourable senators to bear with me and to understand that, while there is a lot of evidence about which I would like to talk, in my view I am precluded from doing so.

speech.para: I put it to the Senate that the function of select committees, in which we are engaged much more now than we have been hitherto, is a very important extension of the work of the Senate. The success of select committees is very much the province of the whole of the Senate, not of any one part of it. I believe that anything which in the end tended to diminishThe status of select committees or to denigrate their work would do harm to the institution which we respect and which we hope will reach a higher status and a greater responsibility.

talk.start.para: - -Prior to the suspension of the sitting I had dealt quite briefly with the genera] position of Senate select committees and with the problems that discussing their activities prior to the preparation of their reports presented to the members of the committees and, I suggested, particularly to the chairmen, who always have to be concerned that the committees operate within the terms of reference laid down for them by their colleagues in the Senate, and also in accordance with the Standing Orders of the Senate which lay down rules for the conduct of our affairs. I am concerned about discussing some of these matters within the terms of the urgency motion as they affect the work of the Senate Select Committee on Off-Shore Petroleum Resources along the lines upon which the Committee was set up in November 1967. I think it would be appropriate if I, in my position as chairman, referred to standing order 308, which no doubt has been dealt with before and I am sure will be dealt with by other honourable senators in the course of this debate. I think it is appropriate to mention some of these things in their proper order. Standing order 308 is a very clear Standing Order, in my interpretation, and has concerned me from the time I became Chairman of the Committee. Standing order 308 states:

quote.para: The evidence taken by any Select Committee of the Senate and documents presented to such Committee, which have not been reported to the Senate, shall not be disclosed or published by any member of such Committee, or by any other person.

speech.para: That Standing Order restrains one, as a member of the Committee, from discussing freely some of the matters that have been referred to earlier and which, I am sure, will be referred to later. I think it is also proper for me to remind the Senate of the terms of reference given to the Committee by the Senate under the resolution passed on 8th November 1967. I propose to read these terms of reference. They are:

item.para: That, with respect to legislation relating to the Exploration for, and the Exploitation of, the Petroleum Resources of the Continental Shelf of Australia and of certain Territories of the Commonwealth and of certain other Submerged Land, a Select Committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report upon:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Whether the constitutional conception underlying the legislation is consistent with the proper constitutional responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States;

item.label: (b)
item.para: whether the system of administration established by the legislation is the most effective to fulfil the purpose of adequate utilisation of Australia's off-shore resources of oil and natural gas;

item.label: (c)
item.para: whether the legislation makes adequate provision for free interstate trade in gas and oil;

item.label: (d)
item.para: whether proper provision is made in the legislation for adequate royalties used in the national interest;

item.label: (e)
item.para: whether the areas of permits confirmed or authorised in the legislation are excessive;

item.label: (f)
item.para: whether proper provision is made relating to renewals to prevent stagnating oil exploration;

item.label: (g)
item.para: whether the legislation makes adequate provision for Australian ownership and/or control or Australian participation in the ownership and/or control of Australia's offshore resources of oil and natural gas; and

item.label: (h)
item.para: the provisions of the legislation generally.

speech.para: When we debated the petroleum Bills it was stated that the legislation was perhaps the largest piece of legislation to pass through the Commonwealth and the States since Federation. The operation is an immense one. Those who are engaged in the work of the Select Committee realise what an immense piece of legislation it was. It took something like 6 years to draw together. About 120 drafts went through the hands of the various draftsmen prior to completion. I read the terms of reference to remind honourable senators, and anybody who may be interested, of the extremely wide range of inquiry placed upon the Committee and therefore how difficult it is in this debate not. to impinge upon some area upon which evidence has been given to the Committee or upon opinions expressed which have not been reported to the Senate. I hope the Committee will permit me to make a progress report of our activities to the Senate fairly shortly. I have the progress report drafted, but I believe it only proper that the Committee as a whole should approve it prior to its being reported to the Senate. In many ways it would have been a good thing if I had been able to present the report this evening, but 1 cannot do that. I will do that as soon as the Committee reads the report and makes the changes that it thinks desirable. The Senate gave the Committee very wide terms of reference so it is entitled to hear the Committee's progress to a certain date. I have referred to standing order 308. I would be indebted to any of my colleagues, and anybody else interested, for any further discussion in which they may care to involve themselves on the meaning of standing order 308. I refer again, briefly, to term of reference (h) which states: the provisions of the legislation generally.

One of the difficulties with which we were confronted in this broad investigation was these areas of what might be called great public interest which were not specifically referred to within our terms of reference but obviously came under clause (h), a fairly wide clause which enabled us to look at and examine such matters. Early in our work it was quite apparent that the problem of drilling in the area of the Great Barrier Reef, and any possible damage that might flow from this drilling, was a matter of public interest not only in Queensland, and North Queensland in particular, but also in Australia generally. We took some trouble to consider the whole matter of our authority - I suppose that is the best word - to take this matter in hand and do what we could to find out about it. We did this. I . will refer to that later. Two facets of the legislation, it seemed to me as chairman, gave us sufficient authority to take some cognisance of this matter. Section 18 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act states: (1.) The Designated Authority may, by instrument published in the Gazette, declare that a block specified in the instrument (not being a block in respect of which a permit or licence is in force or over or in which there is a pipeline) shall not be the subject of a permit, licence, special prospecting authority or access authority and that a pipeline licence shall not be granted in respect of a pipeline over or in that block. (2.) While a declaration under the last preceding sub-section remains in force in respect of a block, a permit, licence, special prospecting authority or access authority shall not be granted in respect of that block and a pipeline licence shall not be granted in respect of a pipeline over or in that block.

I apologise to those who are not fascinated by legal words and who would have some difficulty in understanding that clearly on hearing it the first time. ] want to be fair to the Senate and to tell the Senate of the processes of thinking that went on in order to ensure that, firstly, we were doing what the Senate asked us to do; secondly, we were not in any way doing anything outside our terms of reference; and, thirdly, we were doing what we believed the Senate ought to do, representing, as it does, the broad mass of the Australian people wherever they may be. Section 1 24 states:

quote.para: A person carrying on operations in an adjacent area under a permit, licence, pipeline licence, special prospecting authority, access authority or instrument of consent under the last preceding section shall carry on those operations in a manner that does not interfere with:

item.label: (a)
item.para: navigation;

item.label: (b)
item.para: fishing;

item.label: (c)
item.para: the conservation of the resources of the sea and sea-bed; or

item.label: (d)
item.para: any operations of another person being lawfully carried on by way of exploration for, recovery of or conveyance of a mineral, whether petroleum or not, or by way of construction or operation of a pipeline, to a greater extent than is necessary for the reasonable exercise of the rights and performance of the duties of that first-mentioned person.

speech.para: Those honourable senators who have followed this and have an interest in it will see, 1 think', that there are two areas where quite properly the Senate Select Committee, under term of reference (h) which relates to the legislation generally can look at the difficulties or problems associated with the region which is popularly called the Barrier Reef or the Great Barrier Reef. 1 do not want to canvass the issue of the extent of the Barrier Reef, nor do I want to canvass the possibilities or otherwise of damage because it seems to me that it would be not quite proper to do so. I have expressed the view in the Committee and 1 have also expressed it here in the Senate, that while it is quite in order for people to say that standing order 308 is wide and that they can make their own conclusions about it and behave in their own fashion according to their own interpretation of it, there is placed upon the Committee a very heavy responsibility because under that standing order, for the Committee to divulge its evidence and to speculate upon this mutter could bring upon it or its chairman a charge of breach of privilege.

talk.start.para: - Or on any member who breaches that privilege.

- 1 understand what Senator Branson is saying and that is the reason for my concern. I further say to the Senate that the Committee has been concerned about this because we believe that Senate select committees now operating are inevitably laying down rules which could be called rules of precedent. Every later Senate select committee will have to take notice of these things and will say: 'Well, if it was good enough for them to do it. it is good enough for us.' If, in our case, we are wrong then we are setting the pattern for a series of wrong events. That is why we have been very careful indeed.

speech.para: As I said earlier, there is a great area of public concern about possible activities in the Great Barrier Reef. The Committee recognised this very well and being conscious of it went to north Queensland. It spent the best part of a week in Townsville, in February. My colleagues and I had the fascinating experience of being in Townsville on the hottest day for 45 years. We met in a room with broken down airconditioning. Nobody could say in this instance that the Committee was not prepared to go there and try to find out about conditions in that area. We did our best, on behalf of the Senate, to be available to any person who felt that he had a genuine case to put about the Great Barrier Reef and a genuine concern to express. From the point of view of the Senate, I think this was welcomed by the people in that area. They felt that this was a chance for them to express their views. One did not necessarily always agree with them. After leaving Townsville we went to Brisbane and did some more work in this regard. Since returning to Canberra, the Senate having resumed its sittings, we have done a little more work here. This is what we have tried to do and this will, in due course, come out in our report.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) - Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - I believe it unnecessary to express the importance to Queensland, and indeed to Australia, of the natural wonders of the Great Barrier Reef and the desirability of preserving them. I believe it would be generally acknowledged that as a tourist attraction the Reef would be worth millions of dollars to Australia in terms of direct and indirect spending. However, that alone is not a sufficient basis on which to determine this issue. The exploitation of the Reef is a national problem and one that must be tackled by the national parliament. As the Great Barrier Reef is one of the wonders of the world it is unnecessary, I believe, to stress its importance, but as a representative of Queensland it is necessary to stress the real fears of the people of Queensland that insufficient is being done by the Commonwealth Government to preserve the Reef. Surely their fears are well founded when they read the statement made by the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn) who said that while the Government was concerned that any proposal to mine at the Great Barrier Reef might lead to damage or desecration of this magnificent wonder, we cannot ignore the fact that we do not know where our power lies in this direction.

speech.para: Mr Deputy President,here we have a responsible Minister of the Crown saying that he does not know where the powers of the national government lie in relation to the preservation of the Great Barrier Reef. What a statement to make! There was no indication as to how the Federal Government was endeavouring to extend its influence in this matter; there was no indication of discussions between the Federal and State Governments aimed at resolving the situation; there was no indication of the Federal Government exerting all the power at its disposal.

I have always believed that in the federation of Australia, where the statutes of the State and Federal parliaments conflicted the Federal statutes were supreme. In those circumstances I suggest that the national parliament should see that its powers in this direction are supreme. However, at the present time we have a negative approach on the part of the Minister for National Development. He does not indicate that there is to be any change in approach. I suggest that the Commonwealth Government and the Commonwealth Parliament are not so slow to enforce their supremacy in other directions. For instance, in the trade union field, if a branch of a union has a rule which differs from that of the federal union the branch rule is disallowed. I believe the same procedure should be adopted in this matter under discussion because I believe all would agree that the control of the Great Barrier Reef is a national responsibility and should not be left at the discretion of any State.

We appear to be doing nothing positive about the Great Barrier Reef. We seem to be hoping that something will turn up. This was evident from the remarks of the Minister yesterday in another place. In his speech he said that the Commonwealth is unlikely - and I stress the word 'unlikely' - to grant future applications to mine in the area of the Great Barrier Reef until more is known of the possibility of damaging the Reef. Yet the State Government ofQueenslandisatthisverymomentcon- sidering the granting of leases to institutions to mine the Great Barrier Reef. The Queensland Government probably has before it at this very moment an application from a consortium to mine the Reef, the principal of the consortium being no less a person than the Premier of Queensland who has a substantial number of shares in it.

What will be the situation if we, as the national parliament, say that we do not know where our powers lie in this direction while the State Government grants a permit or lease to mine the Reef? Surely we have a responsibility to Australia, and indeed, to the world, to say that we shall do everything possible to preserve this natural wonder for posterity. Could it be that the application now before the Queensland Cabinet is being considered because of the factors I have outlined; inasmuch as a consortium has made the application? I repeat that the Premier of Queensland is a principal shareholder in that consortium, holding 1 million shares of a total of 15 million. I repeat that this is a particularly shameful proposal and the national Government should see that it does not come to fruition. It is criminal even to consider any application to mine an area before proper precautions in the way of adequate investigations are taken. And those precautions must be taken at this stage. I am confident that honourable senators will agree with me that as yet no proper investigation has been made. Indeed, the Minister for National Development admitted that yesterday in another place. If this is to be the way in which the national parliament treats the situation with regard to one of the great wonders of the world then I believe future generations will look upon the national parliament with some degree of disgust for not having protected the interests of Australia.

Let us examine the dangers inherent in the granting of a licence to mine in this area. Firstly there is the danger of possible immediate damage to the Reef. Secondly, a well having been sunk, who can guarantee that an incident similar to the Bass Strait happening will not occur? Thirdly, oil having been found, what are the dangers of a ship loaded with oil foundering on the Reef, and what damage could result therefrom? ls it worth the risk to endanger one of the wonders of the world in order to find petroleum? This is the question which honourable senators must answer in arriving at a decision on this motion. If they are thinking only of immediate gain they will answer yes, because they will be looking for a dollar. On the other hand, if they answer no, then they will be indicating that they are conscious of the worth to Australia of preserving the Great Barrier Reef in its natural state as against any immediate monetary gain. I suggest with respect that the Government is not doing all that it could do to protect the Reef. We on this side say that no mining leases should be granted until proper investigations have been made, and we implore this Government to do its utmost to influence the Queensland Government to adopt a similar attitude and thus protect one of the great wonders of the world.

I have referred to the remarks of the Minister for National Development in another place. After hearing those remarks, is it any wonder that the Opposition brings forward this emergency motion which refers to:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted.

speech.para: We know that the Minister himself is genuinely concerned that irreparable damage may be done to the Great Barrier Reef should mining operations continue in that area. Consequently I submit the Opposition is justified in bringing this emergency motion forward so that honourable senators might express their dissatisfaction with the way in which this problem has been approached up to date. I repeat that I do not believe that the national Parliament has exercised sufficient power in dealing with the problem. 1 believe that it is the responsibility of the national Parliament to use its powers, because the Great Barrier Reef is somthing that should be preserved for the future of Australia.

Senator SCOTT

talk.start.para: - 1 have noted with interest what the honourable senator has said. The interesting feature about his remarks is that he criticises the Commonwealth Government in respect of some action that it might take to exercise control over the Great Barrier Reef. It must be remembered that, under the off-shore legislation that was passed some time last year-
- You are a year out.

- Or the year before, under that legislation the designated authority is given the power to grant leases. That designated authority may be a State officer, but the Commonwealth retains the right of veto. It is all very well for members of the Labor Party to criticise us for what action they think the Commonwealth Government might take. What happened when a Labor government was in office? It granted the only lease in perpetuity to mine tin on the Queensland coast. Honourable senators opposite may attempt to contradict that if they wish, but the fact is that a Labor government granted a company a lease in perpetuity for the mining of tin on the Queensland coast, and everybody in Queensland was disgusted at its action.
- They are pretty disgusted today.

- And we are disgusted at the Opposition's attitude. But we want to discuss the facts of life so far as oil is concerned. I say at the outset that the Government is appreciative of the wonderful asset we have in the Great Barrier Reef which extends for some 1,200 miles along the coast of Queensland. 1 understand that the Queensland Department of Mines received two applications for permits to drill for oil adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef. The sites were 18 miles away from the Reef. One was the Elliston Reef and the other was Pentecost Island. The application for a permit to drill adjacent to Pentecost Island was refused by the Queensland Government.

speech.para: Anyone who peruses the speech made by the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn) in another place must agree that we are working in complete harmony and unanimity with Mr Camm, the Queensland Minister for Mines, Main Roads and Electricity.

talk.start.para: - That is no recommendation.

- That, of course, is a stupid statement. I do not want to get tangled un in that. The Minister for National Development said in another place that he had had discussions with the Queensland Minister of Mines about the Great Barrier Reef and the Queensland Minister of Mines said quite clearly-

- I rise to order. I was taken to task earlier today for reading from yesterday's Hansard. I now draw attention to the fact that the Minister for Customs and Excise is quoting directly from yesterday's Hansard.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- This question has been raised to me from time to time, but where a Minister or a senator has referred casually to a Hansard report I have lel it go.

talk.start.para: - The members of the Opposition can always give it, but they can never take it. I shall go on with my speech in my own sweet way and I shall not quote from Hansard if I can possibly avoid it. The Queensland Minister for Mines is reputed to have said that he has known that there has been a great deal of controversy over the Great Barrier Reef. He should be one person in Australia who at least knows as much about this matter as anybody else because he has lived on the Great Barrier Reef. Indeed, the Reef is in his electorate. Because it is in his electorate he has made a complete study of it. I should like honourable senators to know that 1 also have been in a position to make a complete study of parts of the Barrier Reef. Having heard of the Reef's great tourist potential I visited it in August last year. I went out to Green Island, which is off Cairns, and 1 was amazed at the great tourist potential of that island. I was told, and T believe, that Green Island has the only observatory in the world where people can go below the surface of the water and look outside the observatory to see the fish.
- Who was looking at whom?

- They were looking in to see me. At all other places throughout the world the fish are in the observatory and one looks in to see them. I was very impressed by what I saw. While in the observatory we saw hundreds of different species of fish swimming about within a few feet of us. I thought that the colours of the Great Barrier Reef were some of the most marvellous and dazzling colours that would be available for one to see in any part of the world. Honourable senators opposite have said that the Government must be most careful about what it does in relation to the Great Barrier Reef and Senator Keeffe has objected to my reading from Hansard. I agree with his objection, up to a point, but I thought it necessary to read this passage and to memorise it because it is quite important and relates to the approach to the mining industry taken by some honourable senators. Members of the Opposition in another place have said that there should be no mining or drilling in searching for oil within 100 miles of the east of the Great Barrier Reef. Of course, this is very learned stuff because the maps reveal that the depth of the ocean 100 miles east of the Great Barrier Reef is probably greater than the depth to which any well can be drilled at the moment.
- There is a new technique in America at the moment.
- They can drill to 12,000 feet.

- Honourable senators opposite are saying, in effect, that no one should bc permitted to drill within 100 miles of the Great Barrier Reef on either side of it - and there is land to one side of it - even if this area, which would be about 100 miles wide and 1.200 miles long, contained the richest oil fields in the world.
- How could Australia prevent anyone from drilling there who wanted to do so?

- That is what they have said. This suggestion needs consideration. I do not agree with what Senator Milliner said about the Minister not being responsible. He is a responsible person and is aware of the significance of the Great Barrier Reef. The honourable senator concluded his remarks by saying that the Commonwealth Government, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, should be aware of its responsibility to preserve the tourist attractions of the Great Barrier Reef.

speech.para: Let us look at the position of oil drilling in Australia and consider what the Government has done. In the interests of the industry and in the interests of the Commonwealth and State governments we have appointed a Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources and the Committee has been given terms of reference. As a Senate we have said to the Committee:

quote.para: That, with respect to legislation relating to the exploration for, and exploitation of, the petroleum resources of the continental shelf of Australia and of certain Territories of the Commonwealth and of certain other submerged land, a Select Committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report upon -

item.label: (a)
item.para: whether the constitutional conception underlying the legislation is consistent with the proper constitutional responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States;

speech.para: It is very important to find out exactly where we stand with regard to constitutional problems relating to oil search and the oil rights off the coast of the States of Australia and in determining whether an area is Commonwealth territory or belongs to the States. These are among the things that the Committee is empowered to investigate. The terms of reference continue:

item.label: (b)
item.para: whether the system of administration established by the legislation is the most effective to fulfil the purpose of adequate utilisation of Australia's off-shore resources of oil and natural gas;

speech.para: The Committee has been set up to inquire into this aspect of oil search. At the moment the Committee is making a complete examination of all these aspects of oil drilling in Australia and on the particular subject of off-shore resources of oil and natural gas. The Committee has been taking evidence and it will present its report on these subjects. I do not propose to refer to all the terms of reference, but I remind the Senate that the Committee is empowered to mates recommendations to the Senate as to what the Government should do in respect of the problems that have been raised during the debate on this motion introduced by the Labor Party. The urgency motion refers to the failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted, but that is a subject which will be examined and analysed completely by the Select Committee. All that the Labor Party is en deavouring to do is to play political football as it did with the Chowilla Dam and as it has been doing over the last fortnight on another issue. Its purpose is to gain a cheap political advantage.

talk.start.para: - What is the Government's policy?

- Senator Cohen is a left wing member of the Opposition and he knows what he is saying. The honourable senator has taken part in the debate on a subject that has been referred to tonight in relation to a certain gentleman whose name I shall not mention because I do not want it splurged all over Australia.
- The Minister will cop it tomorrow.

- We are prepared to cop anything that the Opposition may like to give us tomorrow and we will enjoy it. Honourable senators opposite have used the subject of the Chowilla Dam as a political football.
- Tell us about the Barrier Reef and your policy.
- First the Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects and talks about the Chowilla Dam and now he interjects and says: 'Come back to the Great Barrier Reef.
-I said nothing about the Chowilla Dam.
- I ask you to listen carefully, because you came flat on your face in your endeavours-

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT- Order!

talk.start.para: - I mean the Labor Party, Mr Deputy President, not Senator Cohen. I do not want to cast any reflections at all on the honourable senator.I am simply saying that members of the Labor Party fell flat on their faces as far as the Chowilla Dam is concerned and are liable to fall flat on their faces in relation to this particular motion we are discussing tonight.
- Paul Hasluck said that Ministers could fall on their faces, too.
- If you could make me fall flat on my face, I have no doubt you would do so. The matters referred to in the motion we are debating are being looked after completely, in every aspect, by the

speech.para: Select Committee set up to examine and report upon them to the Senate. The Australian Labor Party has members serving on the Committee and they will make their recommendations.
