The Opposition should wait until the report is available and then, if it does not like its contents, it can criticise the Government. 1 absolutely deplore the action of the Labor Party in bringing this motion before the Senate tonight.

talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democratic Labor Party
talker.name: GAIR, Vincent
Senator GAIR

talk.start.para: - As a member of the Senate Select Committee appointed to examine and analyse the very important off-shore oil exploration and exploitation legislation passed by the Commonwealth Parliament I desire to express my disappointment that: the important question of the Barrier Reef and its future should be the subject of a debate as a matter of urgency in the Senate this evening. I share the views expressed by Senator Cotton, Chairman of the Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources. I have endeavoured lo conform to standing order 308 and to reserve the deliberations of the Committee as a subject of debate until our work is completed and we are in a position to report to the Senate in conformity with the requirements of Senate Standing Orders.

speech.para: I believe that the question of the future of the Barrier. Reef is too all-important to discuss in these circumstances. As a member of the Select Committee appointed by the Senate I believe I am restricted in my contribution to this debate if I am to continue to conform to standing order 308. It states very definitely and without any ambiguity that in my position 1 am not to disclose the deliberations of the Committee until its report has been presented to the Senate. Senators of all political shades from all States are members of the Committee. I say without hesitation that there is not one member of the Committee who is not genuinely and sincerely concerned and interested in the future of the Barrier Reef, irrespective of which State he comes from and the Party he represents. Not one member of the Committee has a monopoly of interest in or concern about the future of the Barrier Reef. Every Australian accepts the Reef as one of the wonders of the world, as it would be classified by most visitors from overseas who have been privileged to see it.

I wonder what is the real purpose of this debate tonight, lt is being conducted prematurely before the Committee has had time to submit its report. Is it because this debate is being broadcast and someone believes that he can gain a cheap political advantage?

talk.start.para: - Is that why you are speaking in it?

- I am speaking in defence of the work of the Committee. If 1 were not as concerned about the Barrier Reef as Senator Keeffe is 1 would not claim to be a Queenslander. I repeat: Is it because the deliberations and proceedings of the Senate are being broadcast tonight that someone thinks he can gain a political advantage? It is a very poor political outlook and a very feeble attempt to gain an advantage. Every member of the Committee is just as concerned about the future of the Barrier Reef as is Senator Keeffe, who introduced this debate into the Senate this evening.
- But time is running out.
- I believe that time ran out completely a long time ago for the Australian Labor Party.
- We are talking about the Barrier Reef.

- I see. All the honourable senator's statements are confusing to himself and to those to whom he addresses them. Senator Milliner very magnanimously surrendered the Great Barrier Reef to the Commonwealth Government. As a Queenslander I do not. I believe that the Barrier Reef belongs to Queensland and that it is the responsibility of the Queensland Government to see that it is properly protected. I cannot go into the subject of the evidence that has been submitted for and against the exploitation of the Reef for oil. I have already explained that as a member of the Committee I am pledged to observe the Standing Orders. It will suffice to say that I cannot for the life of me imagine that any responsible person in the Commonwealth Government or any State government would knowingly and consciously permit exploration for oil on the Barrier Reef unless he was completely and entirely satisfied that the exploration could be carried out without any adverse effect on the Reef, in part or in whole.
- That is what we want the Government to say. You are saying it, but will the Government say it?

- Senator O'Byrne is a member of the Committee as I am. He has heard the evidence of responsible men in the north and in Brisbane, including evidence from a chief mining engineer. He has heard evidence from legal men who participated in the long deliberations that after a period of 6 years brought forth the legislation. Six States reached agreement with the Commonwealth on this unique legislation. Indeed, it was an epochal event for six States and the Commonwealth to come to agreement on anything. I do not subscribe to the view that a Minister of the Crown in Queensland or anywhere else, irrespective of his political party, would be so irresponsible as to approve of work being done on the Reef until he had had evidence to satisfy him beyond doubt that the work could be done without damage to or destruction of the Reef.

speech.para: I would like to have had a real debate on the Reef in this chamber tonight and I would have enjoyed it, just as I am sure everyone who is privileged to listen to a debate on such an important matter as this would have enjoyed it. But in the circumstances we are not able to have that debate. It is to be regretted that the matter was introduced in this way - prematurely and ill-conceived. It occurs to me that senators selected to do the responsible work of committee investigation are not given very much security in the work they are doing.

talk.start.para: - It is a public committee.

- It is a public committee but very lengthy periods of its deliberations are in camera and are subject to the Committee's decision in that regard. But I wonder whether in future senators would be desirous of serving, or even anxious to serve, on committees if they feel that the very subject matter they had been appointed to investigate would be raised for discussion.
- A very good point.

- At the present time my inclination is to tender my resignation from the Committee. I have been a regular attender at the sessions of the Committee and have found them to be most interesting, educational and informative, but for all that I find that a Committee member wants to go off on his own representing himself as the great defender of the Great Barrier Reef and giving the impression that the other members of the Committee have no concern about its future and would sacrifice it to the oil companies. That is my present inclination. If this is to be the pattern of conduct of members of committees in the future I feel that a committee will be just a waste of time.

speech.para: I inform the Senate that it can rely on the Committee that it has selected to take every precautionary measure, and that the Committee will exert every effort and make every possible attempt to ensure that the Great Barrier Reef is not destroyed or damaged in the exploration for oil. I cannot say any more than that. To suggest that the appropriate Commonwealth Minister or State Minister cannot be relied upon is, 1 think, stretching the bow a bit too far. To refer to the State Minister as someone who is not responsible enough to be interested-

talk.start.para: - And he is not here to defend himself either.

- That is right. If the Commonwealth Minister or the State Minister agrees to the grant of a permit or a licence to carry out this exploration or exploitation, whichever you like - one precedes the other, of course - and the Reef is damaged, he will win the wrath of the people. He will have to face 'the people and answer for what he has done.
- It is too late then.
- Then it is too late.
- The honourable senators on my right, who normally are on the left-
- Always.

- Well, normally. They would have you believe that there is no other threat to the Reef. Before the question of oil exploration is considered at all there is a danger from oil tankers which travel the coast of Queensland delivering oil to Cairns and Townsville and other points. If a tanker was unfortunate enough to be wrecked or damaged and there was a leak from it and the oil was swept to the Reef, the Reef could be damaged just as badly as any exploration would damage it - that is, if oil has the damaging effect that we believe it has. But even in regard to that matter there is a difference of opinion by people engaged in scientific research into these questions. I do not want to proceed any further because I will be enticed into the field of evidence, and I do not want that to happen. Let me reiterate that 1 support, concur in and share the views of the Chairman of the Committee as expressed at the outset of his speech tonight. I say again that it is to be regretted that this debate has been brought on and that this matter unquestionably has been made a party political football.

speech.para: Senator WEBSTER(Victoria) 18.57] - Any honourable senator who prompts a debate in the Commonwealth Parliament on the subject of exploration for or exploitation of oil or minerals within Australia or in the submerged lands of Australia does a service to this Parliament and to the people of Australia. The subject that has been brought forward by Senator Keeffe for debate as a matter of urgency certainly has a two pronged purpose. I do not believe he brought it forward for the protection of the Great Barrier Reef. I believe he brought it forward for purely political reasons, as an election is imminent in Queensland and he is seeking some way of embarrassing the Queensland Government. However, the wording of his proposal does not seek so to do. lt refers to:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted.

speech.para: It will be seen from that wording that the honourable senator has avoided altogether the subject of submerged lands. When I read the motion originally I believed that for the Senate to debate this subject certainly would be contravening the Standing Orders. I do not feel that those honourable senators who, because of the discussions ot the Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources, have criticised Senator Keeffe for bringing this matter forward are being quite fair, having regard to the ruling of the President that the Senate was in order in discussing this subject. Whilst accepting that view. I disagree with it. Standing order 308 provides:

quote.para: The evidence taken by any Select Committee of the Senate and documents presented to such Committee, which have not been reported to the Senate, shall not be disclosed or published by any member of such Committee, or by any other person.

speech.para: The wording is 'any evidence taken". T took a point of order with the Chair when Senator Keeffe, disclosed evidence which, 1 believe, would not be available to the general public. However, the Chair ruled against me. 1 accept the ruling of the Chair that the position is that this subject may now be debated by the Senate.

talk.start.para: - At any time standing order 308 can be broken.

- The Opposition alleges the failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that mining will not be permitted in the area of the Great Barrier Reef, lt is interesting to note the words of the Queensland Minister for Mines, Main Roads and Electricity, the Honourable R. E. Camm, when speaking to a mining bill in November of last year. He said: 1 wish to remind the honourable member that it was an ALP Government which issued the only dredging licences which have ever been issued in perpetuity. 1 remind him that they were for mining of mineral sands on the Queensland coast and they cannot now be repudiated.

speech.para: In actual fact, Senator Keeffe wishes to advise this Government that it should give adequate assurance that mining such as was allowed in perpetuity by a Queensland Labor government will not be permitted now. He wishes us to break the assurance that was given by that Labor government.

talk.start.para: - In what year was that?

- That statement was made in November of last year. Some very interesting points are associated with mining in the Great Barrier Reef. If as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources I am allowed to traverse one or two of my own thoughts in relation to this matter, 1 must say that I myself certainly have informed this Senate that 1 am concerned that permits to explore for oil in the Great Barrier Reef and in submerged lands may be granted. It is a ridiculous proposition that we hear from Senator O'Keeffe to the effect that this Federal Government has no right whatsoever to advise the Queensland Government-

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Wood) - Order! The honourable senators name is 'Keeffe'. I think Senator Webster should know that. The honourable senator's name is 'Keeffe', not 'O'Keeffe'.

talk.start.para: - 1 accept your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. The honourable senator suggests that we should exercise some right over the Queensland Government, with respect to the granting of licences on islands in the Reef. This Commonwealth Government has absolutely no control of the land areas of Queensland. But it has some control in submerged lands. 1 believe that the Commonwealth Government should administer its responsibility by obtaining some greater authority to control the exploitation of submerged lands in the Great Barrier Reef.

speech.para: I put the point, forward in a question which I thought was a much better way of doing a service not only for the State of Queensland and its people but also for the Australian people as a whole. You may remember my question asked at the beginning of this session, Mr Acting Deputy President.

talk.start.para: - Remind us of it.
- I will, lt appears at page 167 of Hansard of 27th February 1969. I said:

quote.para: I address a question lo the Leader of the Government in the Senate, or lo the Minister representing the Minister for National Development, whichever Minister considers this matter of sufficient importance lo his portfolio. My question relates to the granting of oil exploration permits hy [i designated authority under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 and the associated agreement.1!, ls it a fact that a designated authority, in grunting an exploration permit, grants the approval of both the State and the Federal governments? Is it known to the Federal authorities, and is it a fact that the Queensland Government is likely within the next few days to announce (Ite successful applicants for exploration permits over a considerable area of the Great Barrier Reef? Will the granting of such permits indicate the Commonwealth's acquiescence in exploratory drilling for oil in the Great Barrier Reef area? ls the Minister or Ministry aware that oil exploration companies are at this point of time unable to give an assurance that no damage will occur to the various interests of the Great Barrier

Reef should an oil leak occur such as happened in the Santa Barbara Channel in the State of California, United States of America? Will the Minister consider that wisdom might suggest that an announcement of successful applicants for exploration permits in this particular area should be delayed until such an assurance can be given?

talk.start.para: - lt sounds like the Forsyte Saga'.

- Indeed, the honourable senator is right. He will find that demonstrated from this corner of the Senate on many occasions. The fact is that at this point in time there is no knowledge or method known in the world - 1 speak not from evidence presented to the Senate Select Committee but from my own experience overseas - as I understand it, to control the flow of oil should such a flow occur in such a submerged drilling. Indeed, had the leak in Bass Strait been an oil flow instead of gas flow it would have been a disaster. What a redundant type of argument it is for Senator Keeffe to put forward in this Senate that an adequate assurance should be given by the Government that no oil drilling or mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will be permitted - full-stop. None will ever be permitted! Surely there is enough intelligence in this Senate to appreciate that some progressive thinking takes place somewhere in the world - even though it may not be on the left side of the Senate - and that in due time it will be possible to control an oil flow if there should be a leak such as occurred in the Santa Barbara Channel.

speech.para: Incidentally, you may recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I asked a question on this very point in the Senate, lt appears at page 170 of Hansard of 27th February 1969. Wishing to avoid the very difficult position of discussing a matter that is before the Senate Select Committee on Off-Shore Petroleum Resources, I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Transport, Senator Scott, this question:

quote.para: Can the Minister representing the Minister for National Development advise the Senate of the preparations which have been made by either Slate or Commonwealth authorities to reduce the incidence of damage which may occur should an oil tanker founder and break up on the Australian coast? ls it a fact that no preparations arc in hand which would be effective to meet such an occurrence? Would the Minister request hi* Department lo meet appropriate State authorities and give urgent consideration to this important matter?

speech.para: I believe that question time in the Senate is for this purpose. In a very wide and new field of legislation and remembering that there are six States joined with the Commonwealth in this matter, I feel that it is necessary to alert any authority as to what should be done for the protection of certain areas of our coast. Indeed, it may not be on the Great Barrier Reef where the first oil tragedy of this type may occur on the Australian coast. We should be well aware and well alert as to what can be done.

Indeed, there are moves afoot these days whereby, if a tanker founders, it is possible to use polystyrene type submerged pontoons which can be floated around the stricken vessel and used to control it so that it can be dispersed at a later date. When I was in New York last year, I viewed a film of the use of a disperser which is put out by the Esso organisation. This is able to be sprayed on the surface of the water and so granulate the oil and make it possible for bacterial action in the sea to disperse the oil by natural methods. It is redundant for the Opposition to put forward the suggestion that no permit should be granted particularly when the Australian Labor Party was the first one to breach this suggested principle some years ago by granting permits for dredging on the Queensland coast. The Opposition should be greatly dishonoured by the facts which have come to light this evening.

May I congratulate Senator Cohen. He is one member of the Labor Party in the Senate who raised last year a question, which was answered, regarding what companies have been granted oil or mining exploration leases in the Great Barrier Reef area. The answer is very interesting. I suggest that honourable senators look at it on page 83 of the Senate Hansard. The point that I make in relation to the terms of reference of the Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources is that this question may have produced the first answer to the first term of reference. Senator Cohen asked:

quote.para: Are any ot these companies actively engaged in oil or mineral exploration on their lease areas; if so, which companies?

speech.para: The reply that was given is the first instance in which a Minister may have abrogated his ministerial obligation to the Federal Parliament. The Minister for National
Development (Mr Fairbairn) said this in the answer that he gave:

quote.para: The titleholders are responsible for carrying out the exploration programmes required by the terms of their titles. The detailed administration of these matters is the responsibility of Queensland.

speech.para: In short, the question and answer produced the view that we in the Federal Parliament may not be able to obtain answers to questions relating to this joint legislation.

talk.start.para: - That would be pertinent to paragraph (b) of the Select Committee's terms of reference.

- I remember that Senator Wright argued this point when the legislation was before this chamber. 1 do not doubt that some of the points that he put forward then will prove to be correct in the long run. The Great Barrier Reef is an important area. Not one member of the Senate would not wish to see it protected. I wish to see it protected. 1 took the normal course of asking questions in the Senate in order to alert the Minister for National Development. I am pleased to know that the announcement made in Queensland - that the allocation of oil search permits would be announced during March - has been retracted for the time being.

speech.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Alister McMullin) - Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - I refer honourable senators to a map of Queensland that appeared in the 'Queensland Government Mining Journal' of January 1969. If they care to peruse that map they will see straddled across the area of the Great Barrier Reef the lease allocations and lease areas. I also refer honourable senators to page 7 of that document which, under the heading 'Off-shore Applications', says:

quote.para: Applications for permits under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act of 1967 for designated off-shore areas Q/1PA and Q/14PA closed on January 2.

speech.para: Then under various headings are listed the firms that applied for the lease areas. The Queensland Minister for Mines, Mr Camm, promised that this week he would announce the successful applicants. That simply is the reason for the urgency motion that has been brought before the Senate today. It is urgent that we clear up the area of dispute as to who has the authority to grant these leases. The heading "Area Q/1PA' has listed below it the names of about forty companies that applied for it. The heading Area Q/2PA' has listed below it the names of about thirty companies. The numbers of applicants foi the rest of the areas then fall away. 1 suggest that this matter should be resolved immediately. We on this side of the Senate are considerably concerned about the activities of the present Queensland Government, lt has been said here tonight that not one off-shore lease has been granted. But that is not so. Exoil NL was awarded lease Q/8P under the transitional provisions of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act as from 1st September 1968. That off-shore lease was granted to Exoil NL, which is a company about which 1 have been asking questions in this chamber. The reason why I have been doing so is that one of the prime movers in the establishment of Exoil NL was the present Premier of the State of Queensland.

talk.start.para: - That is the only reason why the Opposition wanted this Great Barrier Reef matter brought forward as an urgency motion. It wanted to play politics.
- That is not the reason for the urgency motion. The reason for it is that we believe that the present Queensland Government led by the Premier is not a fit body to decide-
- Order! The honourable senator will not pursue that line of argument.
- Will you please explain why, Mr President?
- Order! The honourable senator must not reflect on the Queensland Government. 1 will not allow him to do so.
- I am afraid I must insist that the present Queensland Government is not in a position to deal impartially with the matter.
- Mr President, I raise a point of order, ls it correct for Senator Georges to help to fight the Queensland State election in a Senate debate?
- Order ! There is no substance in the point of order, but I suggest that Senator Georges should not pursue that line of argument.

- I will try to moderate my approach. However, I feel strongly on this matter. Earlier tonight Senator Scott indicated that the Queensland Minister for Mines, Mr Camm, was considerably concerned about the Barrier Reef; that he lived close to it; and that he thought it was a place of great beauty. But let me refer to the Queensland 'Government Gazette', No. 23, which contains a notice of grant of permit Q/8P signed- by Mr Camm. Mr Camm - the Minister who showed such concern about the Great Barrier Reef - was the man who signed away a lease within the Great Barrier Reef area. He signed it away to a company in which his leader is one of the major shareholders. I am sorry, Mr President, but I must insist that this is fair political comment. I suggest to honourable senators that if they want to make a quick quid they might have a look at the list of areas available for lease and look particularly at area Q/9PA.
- Why does not the honourable senator bid for it himself?

- There are no applications for that area. I suggest to honourable senators that they pay $4 and obtain the right to explore or exploit that area. If they have the facilities of one member of the Queensland Government in particular, they could turn that $4 into $720,000 within the space of 4 years. This is a dangerous situation. Oil exploration - something that we badly need - is being used not to find oil for the benefit of Australia but to make a kill on the share market. I believe that it is a reasonable comment to make that the activities of the present Queensland Government and the improper behaviour of certain of its Ministers place in doubt its ability to supervise the exploitation-
- Mr President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator referred to Queensland Ministers acting improperly.

- Order! I have been endeavouring to keep Senator Georges from going completely off the rails. An honourable senator is not allowed to impute improper motives to another parliament. That is quite wrong. Senator Georges should confine himself to the Standing Orders. If he does not I will stop him.

- I represent Queensland and I have to live under the Queensland State Government. I submit that in Queensland a conflict of interest endangers the future of the Barrier Reef. I hope that does not offend the sensitivity of honourable senators opposite. The matter in question is an important one. The recent transactions in Queensland, with one lease having been granted by the present Queensland Government, are cause for concern and cause for urgency in this House. Mr Camm was to have made a statement yesterday, 4th March 1969, regarding which applicants were successful, but this statement has been held back; posibly for two reasons. Honourable senators opposite may say that I am not charitable, but I think the reason why the names of the successful applicants have not been announced is that one of the prime leases has been applied for by the company that I mentioned before, Exoil (NL), in which a Queensland Minister has considerable holdings. But I will be more charitable than that. Yesterday Mr Fairbairn stated that the Commonwealth is unlikely to grant future applications to mine in this area - the Reef - until more is known of the possibility of causing damage. I am prepared to accept that that statement has thrown the Queensland Government into a flap. It is not prepared to announce the names of the successful applicants. I took time off to ask someone to ring the Queensland Department of Mines, which would not say a word. It would not state when it was likely to announce the names of the successful applicants. I hope that the statement made by the Minister for National Development is sufficient to make the Queensland Government think twice. I also hope that this debate tonight will make the Queensland Government think again. 1 believe, as all honourable senators on this side believe, that the Barrier Reef must be protected at all costs and should not be subjected to the risk associated with oil drilling and oil exploration. The Reef, as a tourist attraction, has an economic potential far greater than that which it would have if oil were produced in the area of the Reef. Honourable senators should consider all those people who are under the age of 20 years, who are not represented here and who have no voice, and should consider that these people need the Reef as a heritage and as a resort to which they can go to see one of the greatest wonders of the world. The Reef has more economic potential through tourism than it would have if oil were discovered there in large quantities. It is a matter of urgency that we should take great care. As 1 suggested before, time is running out. If the Queensland Government is permitted to proceed with the granting of applications and if the oil companies defy the Commonwealth Government, all the work that has been done by the Senate Select Committee will have been wasted. It is urgent that something should be done now. 1 ask honourable senators to support the motion.

- I am surprised and I regret very deeply that the Opposition has seen fit to move an urgency motion on a subject such as this. In November 1967 the Senate Select Committee on Off -Shore Petroleum Resources was established to consider all the aspects of Australia's off-shore oil areas. It had very wide terms of reference, which covered consideration of such areas as the Great Barrier Reef. Since that time the Committee has worked, 1 consider, being a member of the Committee - as members of other select committees would agree - very effectively, very fully and very conscientiously and has been willing to take evidence from everybody who showed any concern about any aspect whatsoever of the oil industry or of the off-shore areas of the Commonwealth. I thought that the Senate would have shown enough respect for the responsibility and personnel of the Committee to give it the opportunity to presenting its report before certain sections of the Senate, particularly the Opposition members, should see fit to move an urgency motion, to play some other game and to try to weaken the strength, the work and the efficiency of the Committee which has worked so hard. Tonight Senator Gair said that he felt like resigning. ) am not trying to stress the importance of the work of one committee any more than the work of any other committee, but I happen fo be a member of this Committee so I shall speak within this area. I. along with the other members of the Committee, accept full responsibility for what it is doing. 1. along with other members, attended regularly. The Committee meets outside of Senate sitting time and outside of parliamentary time and is working to present a report which it considers, in its judgment, will be in the best interests of the Commonwealth.

speech.para: It is with regret that tonight we see the Opposition moving an urgency motion. I discount the Opposition thinking that the Committee is not functioning extremely well. I hope that the Opposition has more respect for the personalities on the Committee than to think that. I hope I am right in my judgment on that aspect. Therefore I look to two alternatives. We now realise, as was pointed out tonight, that this year Queensland will have an election. If we did not realise that before we only had to listen to Senator Georges, when he went out of bounds and took advantage of the President by saying the things which he said. His speech was not a speech on the preservation of the Barrier Reef; it was an election speech and I regret that the honourable senator saw fit to make an election speech at this time in this chamber. If honourable senators opposite see fit to denigrate the Select Committee for the sake of politics I think it is high time that some of them slopped and had a good look at the origin of the parliamentary institution. I agree that in all probability politics provided one of the main reasons why the urgency motion was moved. Another reason - and let us consider this - is that today, Wednesday, the proceedings are broadcast. The Opposition was aware that today the defence statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Gorton) was to be debated. What happened? We are aware that a discussion on defence has been taking place in another place. We are aware also that the Prime Minister has made his statement on defence and that it has been accepted not only by the people of Australia and by the Press of Australia but that it has been accepted and welcomed very warmly by the Prime Minister of Singapore. The Opposition saw fit to try to find some weak spots in the defence statement made by the Prime Minister. It tried to do this in (he other place, Sir, but the plan backfired. The Opposition therefore was nol very keen to speak on defence today while the Senate proceedings were being broadcast so what did it do? It turned to an alternative subject and brought forward an urgency motion relating to the Great Barrier Reef. The Opposition may want to chicken out, but I regret very much that honourable senators opposite have seen fit to denigrate the work of a Select Committee of this Senate.

talk.start.para: - We did not denigrate it.

- The Opposition has denigrated the work of the Select Committee. It knows that members of that Committee have a responsibility. The Committee realises that it must work within the confines of a select committee. If Opposition senators do not believe this, let mc refer again to standing order 308. I will read it again for the benefit of those honourable senators who do not clearly realise what it means. Standing order 308 states:

quote.para: The evidence taken by any Select Committee of the Senate and documents presented lo such Committee, which have not been reported to the Senate, shall nol be disclosed or published by any member of such Committee, or-

speech.para: And very importantly - by any other person.

So how much ground can we cover tonight in this discussion on the Great Barrier Reef? Let me go further on this point. One would think from the way that the Opposition is carrying on tonight that this Select Committee does not even know that the Great Barrier Reef exists. The debate is being broadcast and I will let the people of Australia who are listening - and I hope there are a lot of them - know that the Committee saw fit, before the Parliament resumed for this sessional period, to go to Queensland to take evidence about the very thing that we are discussing tonight, the Great Barrier Reef. The Committee took evidence in northern Queensland. We heard evidence from anybody willing to appear before us. All sorts of evidence dealing with the Barrier Reef was presented to the Committee. The Committee then moved lo Brisbane and there again all who felt they had something to contribute, be it from one point of view or another, were given the opportunity to come along and give their evidence. The Committee has shown conclusively that it accepts the fact that there is a Great Barrier Reef. May I say also that it is very conscious that we have only one Great Barrier Reef. 1 do no intend to say anything more about the Great Barrier Reef. As Senator Gair said tonight, we are privileged to serve as members of the select committee and to do what we consider will be in the best interests of the area in which we work. However, we also know that we have responsibilities to that committee and to this Senate. Therefore it is not for me tonight to comment on evidence that has been given. I could talk very easily about newspaper reports. I am referring to the reports about evidence given to the Committee. However, I am not prepared to speak about the type of evidence that was given to this Select Committee. I will say that we have received evidence which completely conflicts with other evidence given to us. 1 think this shows conclusively that the Committee has a big job to do and a great responsibility when it comes to its final conclusions. Would it be right for a member of the Committee to show any bias whatsoever tonight about aspects of the Great Barrier Reef? I say it would not be right. Is it right for any member of the Senate at this stage to start forcing issues one way or the other about the Great Barrier Reef? I say it is not right.

Members of the Opposition have seen fit tonight to stand up and to spruik, for political advantage, about the Great Barrier Reef. We all know of the possibilities of the Great Barrier Reef and I want to make that point clear; but Opposition members are speaking, as Senator Georges did tonight, in a certain manner and with an extreme political bias. They are trying to take political advantage of a situation and at the same time are denigrating the responsibility of the Committee and the responsibility of those who are members of it. I would say to Senator Georges that if he is so concerned about the Great Barrier Reef why did he not give evidence to the Committee when it was in Queensland? Why did he not give evidence while we were in Townsville or Brisbane? Why has he not bothered to come before the Committee when it has been sitting in this House? He would only have to wait overnight in order to appear before the Committee. We would hear what he has to say. But no; he waited until the Senate debates were being broadcast. Why did he do this? He did so to make political capital. I wonder now. Sir, in all sincerity, which has the greater influence on his mind at the present moment - political gain or the preservation of the Reef. If it is the Great Barrier Reef why did he not come to Queensland and give evidence to us? We were willing to hear what he had to say. I say to honourable senators opposite who have stood up tonight and carried on as they have done, that the Senate Select Committee is a responsible Committee and we welcome those who are willing to give evidence to us. We are doing a job and we will gladly hear evidence on any aspect which a person wishes to bring forward, so long as it comes within the confines of our terms of reference, so that in the long term we will be able to bring down a report which is in the best interests of this Senate, this Parliament and the nation as a whole.

In conclusion I say again that I regret very deeply that this issue has been brought into the Senate before the Senate Select Committee has had time to bring down its report. The subject has been raised either to dodge an issue that the Opposition was not prepared to debate tonight, because the proceedings were being broadcast, or in order to gain help for an election campaign in Queensland because the Opposition thought that this subject might bring it political capital. So far as I am concerned, certain principles should be observed. As a member of this Senate I shall stand up for my principles and pass no comment whatever about the Great Barrier Reef at this stage.

talk.start.para: - I have listened with interest to what has been said by honourable senators on the Government side. Mostly they have been concerned with attempting to impute improper motives to honourable senators on the Labor side.
- I cannot hear the honourable senator.

- I said that you have been most concerned with attempting to impute improper motives to Labor senators. That is not unusual with you, is it? I hoped, Mr President, that there would have been a more analytical and dispassionate approach to this particularly important problem. As we realise, the Great Barrier Reef is a State asset but it is part of the national heritage. 1 should have liked to see a wider motion than the one we are discussing. I think the motion is worthy of serious consideration but I would have liked to see it state that there was to be no despoliation of the Reef until more is known about it.

speech.para: I heard a Minister tonight refer to the Queensland Minister for Mines as having a complete knowledge of the Great Barrier Reef. Let me assure him that no one has a complete knowledge of the Reef; nor has any particular group of scientists. Nor has the Liberal and Australian Country Party Government spent much money in furthering the scientific knowledge of the Reef. The Government has been miserably parsimonious on all occasions. The only place where there is a chair of marine biology is at Townsville and no special grant has been made by the Federal Government through the Department of Education and Science for its work. That is the approach of this Government. There is a small marine biological research station at Heron Island and on one occasion the Government granted $10,000 for that work. The staff there today consists of one scientist and one maintenance officer. These are the only people engaged on full time marine research and located within the precincts of the Great Barrier Reef. Heron Island is part and parcel of the Great Barrier Reef. Irrespective of what an honourable senator on the Government side said, the Reef is all around it.

The Great Barrier Reef is an extraordinary structure; it is the biggest structure ever made by man or animal in the history of the world. It is magnificent and it is attractive. The Government has the responsibility to see that it is maintained in this way. Irrespective of the camouflage that has been introduced into this debate tonight about the Senate Select Committee, we are attempting, Mr President, to do something to avoid the granting of leases to a particular company, if possible. The Government has the right of veto. There is this dual pattern of control. The Government has the right of veto, because there is a dual system of control over exploring for oil in submerged lands. I know the constitutional position with relation to the ownership of the Great Barrier Reef.

talk.start.para: - I hope you can explain it.

- The State owns the Great Barrier Reef but this Government has never bacl the courage to declare the waters between the Reef and the mainland to be Australian waters. This is typical of the lack of courage this Government constantly exhibits. I do not think the Attorney- General (Mr Bowen) has ever explored the possibility of declaring these waters to be Australian waters. After all, they are in fact sea waters covering submerged mainland. The history of the area is that this land was part of the Australian continent many years ago. It is now submerged land, but this Government, has not had the courage to explore the possibility of declaring the waters of the Great Barrier Reef to be Australian territorial waters.

speech.para: Let us look at the position as it really is. Exploring for and mining of oil will not be the only methods of destroying the Great Barrier Reef. Part of it has been destroyed already by the Crown of Thorns starfish as a result of the removal of Triton shellfish by tourists. I do not know whether honourable senators know how the scientists believe that parts of the Reef have been destroyed. It is their opinion that destruction has resulted from the removal of the Triton shells. The ecology of this area is based on the relationship between the Triton and the Crown of Thorns starfish. This is responsible for the preservation of the coral. An infinitesimal organism, the coral polyp has built up this tremendous structure of dead coral with live coral on top of it, surrounded by a multitudinous array of marine organisms and plant life. Yet, when the Labor Party proposes an urgency motion such as the one before us Government senators impute to our members all the improper motives they can possibly devise in their extraordinarily low minds. That is the best way I can put it.

Senator Georgeshas tried to impress upon the Government tonight the concern that he and other honourable senators on this side have to see that no further leases shall be granted. He outlined in detail how a particular consortium of oil exploration companies is seeking to exploit the position. He mentioned Exoil (NL) and Transoil in particular. A Mr Stiller is Chairman of Directors. They are major oil companies.

They are applicants for exploration leases. One lease has been granted already. We must look at this position in a fair, factual way in order to arrive at what is likely to be the outcome. I am not imputing improper motives to the members of the Queensland Cabinet at all. I am merely adopting a realistic, practical, factual approach to the position in which these men are placed. They happen to be cronies or very great friends of their leader, the Premier of Queensland. He had a lease in northwestern Queensland. Fifty-one percent of the shareholding was ultimately taken over by an American company. Then the Exoil company, of which Mr Stiller is Chairman, took over Artesian Basin Oil Pty Ltd, which held the earlier exploration lease, that company being granted I million shares of which the Premier of Queensland holds 49%. He has since bought another 45,000 shares so that he actually owns over 500,000 shares in this oil company. His colleagues are now sitting in judgment to decide whether a company of which he is the major shareholder shall be granted the right to explore for oil in the vicinity of the Great Barrier Reef. Is it any wonder that the Labor Party sees fit to bring forward this urgency motion? It is to Senator Keeffe's credit that he was prepared to submit the motion and so face the odium that Government senators seek to hurl at him.

Let us consider some of the things they have said. It has been said by Government senators that a Labour government granted a tin lease in perpetuity in Queensland. I do not know where they got this information. No Queensland government, whether it be Labor or otherwise has granted any lease in perpetuity in the last 50 years. I think the lease to which reference was made is a coral dredging lease granted to the Queensland Cement and Lime Company when it was running short of lime. It is a lease over a patch of dead coral which is not connected in any way with the Great Barrier Reef. It is in the south of Queensland. I point out for the information of honourable senators on the Government side that the Great Barrier Reef extends from near Torres Strait in the north down to Sandy Cape on Fraser Island, which is just outside Maryborough. It covers a distance of 1,200 miles. No part of the Great

Barrier Reef is off Moreton Bay or anywhere just outside Brisbane at all. The lease mentioned was a dredging lease which was granted by a Labor government to provide the Queensland Cement and Lime Company with a reasonable and permanent supply of coral. But no lease is granted in perpetuity. All leases, whether mineral or oil, are granted for specified periods. The exploration company, or the developing company, has the right to apply for an extension of lease at the end of the specified period and, depending on whether the work they have done or the development they have carried out is satisfactory, approval is given to their application. If what they have done is satisfactory, their lease will almost certainly be extended. This is not unreasonable. It is a reasonable policy, and it ill becomes the members of this Government to seek to besmirch a Queensland Labor government so unfairly and so untruthfully. But, of course, this is but typical of this Government's approach to such matters. And Government senators have the temerity, the colossal impudence and the hide to suggest that we are merely electioneering in submitting this motion.

talk.start.para: - And that is the truth.

- It is not true at all. Anyhow, if it is, what is wrong with that? There is nothing wrong with it. This afternoon, a distinguished lady senator from South Australia who sits on the Government side submitted a couple of questions in which she sought to impute improper motives to Labor senators from South Australia. She sought to enhance the declining prestige of the Liberal Government in South Australia. Is that not electioneering? Is that not trying to bolster up the political party with which honourable senators opposite are associated? Of course it is. We are proud of the Party to which we belong and we look forward to the day when the interests of Australia will be safeguarded by Labor governments not only in the States but also in the Commonwealth sphere.

speech.para: Honourable senators opposite have displayed remarkable ingenuity in finding reasons for our submitting this motion. Senator Young suggested that it was introduced in order to avoid debating the Prime Minister's defence statement. When is the defence statement to be debated here? If the Government wants the debate to be broadcast, the Government could easily put it on for discussion on the Wednesday after we resume. The Prime Minister (Mr Gorton) has been procrastinating for far too long now. Indeed, he has not yet produced a defence plan. He has merely told us that he is going to place some troops in Singapore, some Air Force personnel in Malaya and a ship in the Straits of Singapore. Where is his plan for defence equipment?

talk.start.para: - I rise to order. Are we engaging in a debate on the Great Barrier Reef, or are we now commencing a debate on another matter on the notice paper?

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Laught) - Order! I ask Senator Dittmer to revert to the subject matter of the motion before the Senate.

talk.start.para: - I thank you. Mr Acting Deputy President. 1 do not appreciate that action from an honourable senator whose tolerance I have always admired in the past. It would seem that with age he is getting less tolerant. I was merely replying to what had been submitted by his colleague for the consideration of honourable senators here assembled. I would not have otherwise brought the matter up at all. I would not have been interested. We can defend ourselves. The Government can bring on the debate on defence whenever its suits its convenience. Perhaps Government senators do not want that debate to be broadcast.
- Will you guarantee that we can bring on the defence debate on the Wednesday when we come back?

- Is not that in your own hands? You are the Government? Let us get back to the Barrier Reef. I do plead with honourable senators on the Government side to adopt the approach that has been suggested. In this Barrier Reef we have a magnificent structure. Anyone who has been there has expressed for the Reef an admiration far in excess of that expressed for any other natural phenomenon. In the Great Barrier Reef we have an extraordinary array of colours. We have myriads of different forms of fish, we have a multitudinous array of plant life and numbers of islands of various types. Some are of coral formation; others are of volcanic formation. These have sunk into the sea and, with the coral formations surrounding them present a spectacle which excites the admiration. This great wonder attracts people from all over the world.

speech.para: Do Government members propose only to worship Mammon? Is money all that they think about when considering the search for oil in this area? Is their only consideration going to be the amount of coral that can be taken from the Reef for cementmaking purposes especially when there are tremendous deposits of coral on the mainland. Is this all that is going to be in the minds of Queensland Cabinet Ministers when they see fit to grant oil leases as they have to their Premier? Is monetary reward to be all that spurs them on? We suggest that in the Great Barrier Reef Australia has something of which all can be proud and for which all have a responsibility. The Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn) said that it was unlikely that there would be drilling on the Reef, but he gave no real assurance in the other place yesterday that there would be a preservation of this structure until scientific information was available to show that it would suffer no damage if oil escaped during exploration projects.

Someone mentioned tonight that Mr Morley, the present State Mining Engineer who is likely to retire, appeared before the Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources and said that there was no evidence that damage had been caused by oil. If he had only read the newspapers he would have known what had happened on the south coast of England when a tanker broke up. In that instance millions of dollars were spent in an endeavour not to eliminate the nuisance but to minimise it. There was recently an oil leak in the Santa Barbara Channel off the coast of California, as a result of which the people of that area alone are seeking from the oil company, through the United States Government, damages to the extent of $ 1,300m. That is the result of one oil leak. I believe that since that leak was stopped another has developed. Fish have been destroyed and birds have died. Yet Mr Morley, a witness before the Select Committee, said that there was no evidence that oil in the sea had caused any damage. It is interesting to note that the Premier of Queensland, who has done so much in the interests of the oil industry in that State, did not see fit to appear before the Committee.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Laught) - Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - 1 oppose the motion. The Senate is discussing a motion moved by Senator Keeffe that the Senate should adjourn until tomorrow for the purpose of debating a matter of urgency, namely, the failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted. The moving of this motion at a late stage this afternoon was an exercise by the Opposition of the powers conferred by the Standing Orders of the Senate whereby senators may move that a matter of urgency be discussed. It is significant that if this motion had not been moved the Opposition in this place would have been compelled, through its various spokesmen, to indicate which of its various views on defence put forward by its spokesmen in the House of Representatives they were prepared to espouse. I imagine that was the challenge that was before honourable senators opposite. So we have had a discussion this afternoon and this evening on whether or not oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas should be permitted. The Opposition feels on safer ground with this somewhat innocuous subject than it would be with the very difficult subject of defence on which its views are so numerous that it does not know where it stands.
- I rise to order. Senator Greenwood is not relating his remarks to the motion. He is discussing the subject of defence and not the Great Barrier Reef.

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT - I rule that Senator Greenwood has been in order so far but that he should very soon come to the subject of the Great Barrier Reef.

talk.start.para: - In deference to your ruling, Sir, and if I may be permitted to say so in deference to the sensitivity of Senator Keeffe, because possibly some of the barbs have struck home, I shall now deal with the subject of the motion which is whether or not oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas should be permitted. In a consideration of the urgency of this matter it might be relevant to mention to the Senate that this issue was discussed in the House of Representatives yesterday where the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn), on behalf of the Government, stated explicitly what the Government's attitude was. I should have imagined that if the Opposition was sincere in what it was putting forward today it would have accepted what the Minister said yesterday. But that is not the case. We know that at present the Labor Party feels that in Queensland it may be able to score a point, whereas it has not been able to score points anywhere else in the Commonwealth. There is to be an election in Queensland this year. The Labor Party wants to be able to say to the people of Queensland: 'We will protect the Barrier Reef. To give support to this view it has developed an argument against Mr BjelkePetersen. We have heard some of the most rank and unfair statements that one could expect to hear levelled against this gentleman in this chamber tonight.

speech.para: But leaving that aside, I turn to the terms of the resolution which states that the Government has failed to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted. I must turn to the terms of the motion in order to answer it because nothing that the Opposition has said in the course of this debate has demonstrated what is meant by 'failure to give an adequate assurance'. Not one of the five senators who have spoken has given any indication of what is meant by that expression. That is because they cannot give such an indication. What assurances has the GoGovernment given? First, the Government, through Mr Fairbairn, has said that it values highly the unique characteristic which Australia possesses, namely the Great Barrier Reef. The Government has said that it is worried about the effects of mining on the Great Barrier Reef. It has said that it will do its utmost to ensure that the Great Barrier Reef is not despoiled. Furthermore, the Government has said that it is unlikely to grant future applications for permits until more is known of the possibility of exploration and exploitation causing damage. But let me mention further what the Government has said, lt is useful to indicate to the Senate what the Government has said because the Opposition has chosen to ignore it.

The Government, in conjunction with the Government of Queensland, has the advantage of one of the world's most renowned geologists, a Dr Ladd, who was commissioned to investigate the Barrier Reef and who has presented a report to the Queensland Government. The contents of that report have now been made public. In it he indicated, firstly, the dangers of mining in the Barrier Reef if protective measures are not taken and, secondly, that if protective measures are taken we should be able to protect the Barrier Reef even if mining occurs. The Commonwealth Government is sending an officer of the Bureau of Mineral Resources to America to make an on-the-spot investigation of the leak which occurred at the off-shore rig in the Santa Barbara Channel. The Queensland Government has also sent its senior mining engineer to make a similar investigation. A further fact which I think is relevant is that the Queensland Government has rejected applications for drilling, not for petroleum but for other minerals, at Ellison Reef and Pentecost Island. It is a fact also that at present not one drill is being put down on the Barrier Reef. The Opposition has suggested that the Government has failed to give an adequate assurance. This is a matter which, if it is to be tested, depends upon the power that the Commonwealth Government has to give any assurance at all. lt is this field of power of the Commonwealth Government and of the State Government over the Great Barrier Reef which is comprehended by the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act passed by this Government in 1967. Legislation complementary to that Act was passed in remarkable fashion in each State Parliament. The Act attempts to give to Commonwealth and State authorities a joint control over offshore areas in which petroleum may be found. The legislation was designed in that way after 5 or so years of discussion and negotiations because, in terms of constitutional law, there are many competing views in respect of off-shore areas. Who has authority to determine what shall happen in the seabed off the coast of Australia? Is it the State alongside which the seabed is found, or is it the Commonwealth because the Commonwealth broadly has legislative power in respect of the Commonwealth? These are difficult constitutional matters that could have been fought out in the High Court of Australia as happened in the Supreme Court of Canada, but the result of such litigation would be to create further difficulties which, when clarified, would still have required negotiations and a solution arrived at by the Commonwealth and the States.

The Commonwealth and State governments, showing horse sense of which Australians ought to bc proud, got together and the petroleum (submerged lands) legislation was agreed upon. Such is the pattern of that legislation that the Commonwealth and the State each have independent authority with regard to the Barrier Reef. It may be that if the State had to justify its authority, or if the Commonwealth had to justify its authority, neither would be able to sustain it as a matter of law; but they have agreed that they will collaborate and in that way it is hoped that any problems of constitutional power will be overcome. Acting in that way, the Queensland Government has power over the land mass which constitutes Queensland, and the islands of the Great Barrier Reef area above the low water mark are part of Queensland. In that respect the Commonwealth Government has absolutely no power at all. It would be a strange thing if the Queensland senators who have been protesting so vigorously today were not aware of that fact.

With regard to the seabed areas of the Great Barrier Reef the Queensland Government has certain powers, but it is agreed in the negotiations and the agreement which constitutes part of the petroleum (submerged lands) legislation framework that the power will not be exercised except on consultation with the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is similarly bound. Therefore the Commonwealth has not an absolute power over what happens in regard to drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef. It must consult with the Queensland Government. It is said that the Commonwealth is not satisfied with the general knowledge which exists with regard to possible dangers to the Barrier Reef. In those circumstances it is a voice which is saying: 'Caution'. la sought by the Opposition would be an assurance lacking legal effect and contrary to what has been solemnly agreed between the Queensland and Commonwealth governments.

Members of the Opposition may say, as part of their general1 irresponsible attitude: What do agreements matter? Just override them. On that issue we can avoid them'. That is what would be involved if the Commonwealth were desired to give a more explicit assurance. There are two types of permit currently available for the Great Barrier Reef area. Firstly, there are the permits issued by the Queensland Government before the legislation came into force in 1967. As to those permits the Commonwealth Government has no power at all. They were issued by the Queensland Government and are preserved by the legislation. They are honoured because they were granted before this legislation came into force. Secondly, there are permits which may be granted under this legislation. No such permits have yet been granted, but if permits are to be granted subject to the terms and conditions of the Act one can justifiably suppose that conditions designed to protect the Barrier Reef will be imposed.

The vital issue involved in this proposition is whether all exploration for oil in the Barrier Reef should be stopped or should bc permitted under the most stringent safeguards. The Minister has said that he is not satisfied at present that those safeguards exist. I think that is a very reasonable attitude. The matter of urgency we are debating suggests that the Government has failed to give an adequate assurance. As I have said, it has been raised to seek some political advantage by a desperate and frustrated Opposition. A realistic examination shows that it is a matter of balancing what is in the best interests of Australia, and the determination of whether drilling and mining is to occur in the Barrier Reef must await further information. That is the general approach which the Commonwealth Government, to the limit of its constitutional ability and to the extent of its legislative power, is adopting. For the Opposition to say that in those circumstances an adequate assurance has not been given is to ignore the provisions of the legislation. I repeat that it is an attempt to gain some advantage. Unfortunately, the attempt has been made ignoring the powers of the Commonwealth and without doing the obvious and necessary homework which ought to justify the proposition put forward.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Laught) - Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: - I, like other members of the Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources who have spoken in this debate, do so with a feeling of inhibition as to how far I can go in discussing the matters that have been raised tonight. However, I relieve my mind quite considerably, and I take little notice of standing order 308, because of advice from the Clerk of the Senate as to the disclosure of evidence by the Committee. To free my mind a little in this respect I propose to quote briefly from the advice given by the Clerk of the Senate. In talking about freedom to allow the evidence given before committees to be perused, he said:

quote.para: The important consideration is that the official transcript is prepared for the use of members of the committee and, strictly, should not be disclosed before report to the Senate. Practice, however, allows disclosure of the official transcript to (a) witnesses who have given evidence, for the purpose of correction; (b) prospective witnesses as the committee thinks fit; and (c) such other persons as the committee thinks fit.

talk.start.para: - Then do you not think it is time that the standing order was amended.

- I listened very quietly to honourable senators who have spoken in this debate. There will be time for Senator Branson to make his speech. The advice of the Clerk that a practice has grown up that would seem to have gone over the top of the standing order, or at least to be in conflict with it, considerably relieves my mind. The terms of reference of the Committee have been referred to tonight. However, not all the terms of reference have been referred to. Under item 3 the Committee has power to send for persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in open court or in private. Substantially we sit in open court. The Press is admitted. It is allowed to publish reports of the proceedings and the evidence given is not secret the circumstances, any greater assurance from the public any more than the proceedings of the Senate are secret from the public. The galleries can be filled at any time. So the restrictions that are placed upon senators in speaking in this place on matters with which a Senate select committee is dealing are not so great as they were made out to be earlier in this debate.

speech.para: Has anyone stopped asking questions about health matters because there is a Senate Select Committee on Medical and Hospital Costs? Of course not. Every day there are questions on matters related to the health services in Australia. It is sheer humbug to say that we cannot discuss these matters. I agree with what was said by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Cohen) today to the effect that if we were to adopt literally standing order 308 we would muzzle the Senate for the period that a Senate select committee was in existence. The Senate would not be justified in muzzling itself on any subject that it thought it should discuss.

Now we take it a little further. It has been said by speakers on the Government side that this matter has been raised for political purposes because it is an election issue. However, Government senators are pretty adept in the art of using this Parliament for the purpose of influencing the electorate. If the Liberal Party is allowed to use this Parliament for the purpose of influencing the electorate, I do not know why the Labor Party, the Country Party or the Australian Democratic Labor Party should not have the same opportunities to do so. The day members of the Liberal Party cut it out is the day on which we will cut it out. Even recently when a Minister in this place was under severe pressure the Prime Minister (Mr Gorton), in order to get him off the hook, started to drag a red herring across the trail. He called it a left wing conspiracy. Do not claim that that was not electioneering.
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) - Senator Cant. 1 suggest that you should connect your remarks to the matter before the Senate.

talk.start.para: - With all due respect to you, Mr Deputy President, these matters have been canvassed by speakers on the other side and I think that I am entitled to reply to them. However, out of respect for you I will not go any further on those lines. Although the debate centres on the protection of the Great Barrier Reef, about which the Labor Party is very concerned and about which the Minister for National Development (Mr Fairbairn) and the Minister for Mines in Queensland purport to be very concerned, it is noticeable that not one Queensland senator on the Government side has stood in his place to express his opinion on what should be done with the Reef. I leave honourable senators with those few thoughts on that aspect.

speech.para: It has been said in this debate, and by the Minister in another place, that permits to explore and exploit the Great Barrier Reef area off Queensland will not be issued. It is wrong for people to come into this place and make that kind of statement. It is well known to anyone who has studied the legislation that if a permit was issued to an exploring or an exploiting company prior to the passage of the legislation that permit must be re-issued to the same party in accordance with the transitional provisions of the legislation.

talk.start.para: - You agree, then, that Senator Georges made a very poor point.

- All I am saying is that there are senators on the opposite side of the chamber who would attempt to mislead the Senate in respect of the provisions of the legislation. It is well known that no power is vested in the Commonwealth Minister or the State Minister to withhold permits or licences if permits or licences were held prior to the passage of the legislation. It is true that the work provisions that the Designated Authority may apply to the issue of any permit may be such that they would prevent an applicant or a person holding a permit or a licence being able to explore and exploit. The conditions that he will apply to the issue of a permit are a matter for the Designated Authority, but it is not true to say that permits will not be issued for the Great Barrier Reef areas if permits were issued before this legislation was passed. The very purpose of the legislation was to keep faith with people who had taken out permits to explore the sub-soil of the sea bed on the continental shelf of Australia, lt would be an act of gross bad faith for anyone to refuse the permits, because the transitional provisions of the legislation do not allow anyone to refuse them.

speech.para: My very good friend Senator Greenwood said a little while ago that the Queensland Government had engaged an adviser in the person of Dr Ladd to advise whether the Great Barrier Reef could be protected. It is true that Dr Ladd has submitted a report which has 'become public. The salient feature of that report is that Dr Ladd has said that there should be at least 2 years scientific survey on the Great Barrier Reef before anything is done. We have controlled the Great Barrier Reef for many years and have done practically nothing to explore its possibilities, scientifically or otherwise, yet we have expected Dr Ladd to come to this country and produce a firm and concise report in 2 months on the effect of oil exploration on and exploitation of the Great Barrier Reef. Dr Ladd had only that short period of time but he has recommended that at least 2 years survey work should be done. That is the salient point of his report.

talk.start.para: - Does the proposal mean that permits should be issued at some stage or would you prohibit them altogether?
- I think the honourable senator is able to read as well as I am.
- What are the terms of your proposal?
- It refers to:

quote.para: The failure of the Government to give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef areas will not be permitted.

talk.start.para: - There you are, forever.

- That is right. However, I remind the honourable senator that Senator Scott said today that if we had the greatest oil province in the world in the Great Barrier Reef area it would be unreasonable to expect that we should not exploit it, but you could have the greatest oil province in the world and reap a crop from it for only a limited time. However, you could reap a crop from the Great Barrier Reef for year after year ad infinitum. Irrespective of the amount of oil found there, I believe that the Great Barrier Reef will pay greater dividends to Australia as a tourist attraction than as an oil producing area, but of course the vested interests of overseas capital might determine otherwise. That is what worries Labor Party senators, even if it does not worry Government senators.

speech.para: We feel justified in bringing this matter before the Senate for discussion at this time because, as most honourable senators on the other side who have spoken know, we believe that it will be some time before the Committee which is dealing with this question will be able to present a report to the Senate. Then, it will probably take several months before the Government acts, if it does act, on the report of the Committe. We believe that this is the time when some action should be taken to prevent the Great Barrier Reef from being exploited and destroyed. I say quite frankly: How can the Government give an assurance that the Barrier Reef will be protected, in view of what happened in the Santa Barbara Channel, what has happened on several occasions in the North Sea, what happened to the Moonie pipeline near Brisbane and what happened in Bass Strait? Can this Government give an assurance that no blow out of an oil well or a gas well will occur in the area of the Great Barrier Reef if exploration and exploitation are allowed to take place and continue to take place?

We know that the crop can be reaped every year, year after year but we say that the value of the Great Barrier Reef to the national interest is greater than all the oil that may be found under it. For that reason, we say that the Government should give an adequate assurance that oil drilling and mining in the Great Barrier Reef area will not be permitted. There is no let out for the Government. We say that there should not be any exploration for and exploitation of oft in this area.

talk.start.para: - The honourable senator knows that the Federal Government cannot do that.
- lt ought to try.
- We are all aware that the Liberal and Country Party governments are not interested in the national interest.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Drake-Brockman) - Order! The honourable senator's lime has expired.

talk.start.para: - I rise to pursue a matter which has interested me since I had the honour, by the direction of the Senate, to join a Senate select committee. That committee did me the personal honour of asking me to accept its chairmanship. Honourable senators will recollect that there was a stage where I fell into some sort of bother with one of my colleagues. A matter arose in a debate and evidence that had been given in a meeting of that select committee was quoted in the Senate. The argument turned upon whether the evidence quoted was evidence that was in the executive committee, if I may use the American expression, or whether it was given in open forum. The reason why 1 mention this is that this was the stimulus that caused me to jump to my feet earlier today to take a point of order in respect of the matter raised for urgent discussion by Senator Keeffe and which has been convassed in the Senate for the last 2i hours or 3 hours.

speech.para: The problem has not been resolved. 1 say that notwithstanding the advice entitled Disclosure of Select Committee Evidence' that the eminent Clerk of the Senate, for whom I have a great respect, circulated and which I have not seen because it was circulated to the members of the existing Committee, the fact is that I do not believe that a select committee of the Senate can pursue properly the responsibility that the Senate places upon it when the matters which have been given to that committee and are within its terms of reference can be, at the whim of any senator supported by four other senators standing in their places, subjected to scrutiny in debate in the Senate. The realities of the debate that has taken place in the Senate this afternoon and in the evening are that the forms of the Senate have been distorted for the purpose of partisanship. This is what we have been attempting to make clear. Notwithstanding anything that Senator Cant from Western Australia has said to the contrary - he made out as glib a case as he could - the facts are that the forms of the Senate are being distorted for the purpose of partisanship and this detracts from the efficacy of select committees which should be protected from this sort of operation.

It is for this reason - I am glad to see you back in the Chair, Mr President - that I was prompted to take a point of order this afternoon, supported by my colleagues, Senator Greenwood and Senator Lawrie. I hope that the last has not been heard of the propriety of the matters in which we have been involved. I was heartened tonight by Senator Greenwood who left the strong impression upon me of the young David involved with a sort of collective Satanine Goliath-

talk.start.para: - Who is this?

- They are in the Opposition. It seemed to me symbolic of this Old Testament character that the Australian Labor Party so often assumes, filled with prejudice and partisanship, myopic, living in the past, and trundling out the shibboleths that Senator Cant has trundled out tonight.

speech.para: Whenever there is a mineral discovery, we can calculate and lay down as a certainty that an honourable senator on the Opposition side will get up and say that its development is not in the best interests of Australia. An Opposition senator will say, for instance, that it is not in Australia's best interests that a rocket range should be established and that this will interfere with something. An Opposition senator will suggest that we must not pursue alumina in the Gove Peninsula because of some sacred tribal grounds there or that we must not allow somebody else - this is where the curiosity occurs - to fish for prawns because this is a sacred ground or something else. One can bet one's life that whenever problems of the reasonable extraction of the primary resources of the country are involved one will find in the Opposition someone who will get up and say that this is a bad thing and that it is not in the national interest. Of course it is in the national interest. What is the position when the reporter who has been engaged by the Commonwealth Government and the Queensland Government reports that, without prejudice to the ecology of the Great Barrier Reef, it is possible to extract, let us suppose, gold from sea water? The question is whether this is or is not in the interest of tourist traffic or the Barrier Reef, which is one of the wonders of the world. Tt is not a question of oil or of lime for the manufacture of cement. No-one knows what can be extracted from the sea.
