The matter raised for urgent discussion by Senator Keeffe asks the Commonwealth

Government to give adequate assurances that oil drilling - that has been canvassed - and mining on the Great Barrier Reef will not be permitted. This argument can be extended as far as to take in all other aspects of Australian development. It may be said that it is not in the interests of South Australia to allow oil drilling rigs to operate in St Vincent Gulf because it is not in the best interests of the city of Adelaide. This sort of argument can be pursued to the most illogical conclusion. I suggest that the Senate should not take undue cognisance of what Senator Keeffe has been saying. It should turn its attention to the propriety of using evidentiary matter received by Senate select committees for useful debate and partisanship purposes in this chamber.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Alister McMullin) - Order! The time allowed for the debate having expired, the business of the day will be proceeded with.

subdebateinfo.title: REPORT OF THE STANDING ORDERS COMMITTEE

talk.start.para: -I bring up a report from the Standing Orders Committee relating to the manner of asking questions on notice.

speech.para: Motion (by Senator Anderson) proposed:

quote.para: That the report be printed.

talk.start.para: - Mr President,I believe that we should give this matter some consideration, even before we agree to the report being printed.
- I intend to move subsequently that consideration of the report be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
- All right.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Morion (by Senator Anderson) agreed to:

quote.para: That the report be taken into consideration at the next sitting.

debate.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Scott) proposed: That the Bill be now read a first time.

talk.start.para: - This motion gives any honourable senator the opportunity to discuss more or less any question that he cares to discuss. This debate is similar to a budget debate. In view of the happenings of last evening I desire to discuss matters that have been before the Senate off and on for the last 2 or more days. It is not my intention to deal with Mr Hoffmann at all. I am most touched by the crocodile tears of honourable senators on the Opposition side for any worker who may have made a mistake. In fact, my heart bleeds when I hear what they have to say aboutthe individual concerned in this case.
- I think the honourable senator meant to say ' honourable senators on the Government side'.

- Yes, I meant my friends opposite. I could feel drops of blood from my heart when the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Scott) said: Oh, the poor worker'. I leave the unfortunate individual to himself. I hope that his future life is what he wants it to be. I believe in the old saying that it is human to err and divine to forgive. I am concerned with the matter of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. That is what worries me. Today it seems that anyone who stands up to speak about the Security Service of this country either is left wing or unpatriotic or is one who wants to affect the security of his country. If this Organisation acted only in the field of the security of this country, I for one would have nothing to say against it or even about it. I am not one who believes that we should not have a security service. 1. believe that we should have one. But I believe that it should work within the ambit of its constitution.

speech.para: In this case, irrespective of what anyone says, I believe that the Organisation was in contact with a lady who worked in the Japanese embassy and that she and one officer of the Organisation did something that I believe affects this great nation. I hate to think that in this day and age - not on a matter of security but on a matter, as I understand it, of pure commercial practice - copies of documents were taken from the embassy of a nation which at the moment is friendly, whatever it may be in the future. Why was that done? First of all people are asking: Was it done? I understand that a letter which states that it was done was about this building. Unfortunately I have not a copy of it. But the letter was read within the precincts of Parliament House. It was brought to this building by the lady in question.

talk.start.para: - To whom was it addressed?
- I am not in a position to say to whom it was addressed. All I am concerned about is that it was brought into this building and was read by a person whom I happen to know.
- Who was that?

- It is not my purpose to say who anybody was. The fact is that I am convinced in my own mind that what I am stating is true. If anyone wants to know whether it is true, I ask him to listen to a comment from the one journal in this nation which since 1949 has never seen the Government do a wrong act. I refer to the Sydney 'Telegraph'. The Sunday Telegraph' stated:

quote.para: One thing is certain, Mrs Hoffmann did, in fact, act as agent for ASIO to obtain secret information from the Japanese embassy, where she worked as a trusted secretary.

speech.para: Knowing the political thoughts of the owners of that newspaper, is anyone going to tell me or anyone else in this chamber that they would print something like that against this Government if they did not believe and know that it was true? In the Australian' we read:

quote.para: But at best it is a half-hearted and ambiguous denial.

speech.para: That referred to a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Gorton) on this question. From his high and mighty position, he thinks that the only way to get out of this situation is to use the old dodge of flinging political mud. I regret that he thinks that way. He spoke about the left wing of the Labor Party. I shall trace what has been said, prior to elections, over the years by Governments of his political complexion. In 1917 the Government said that it would win the war. In 1920 it was against the Bolsheviks. In 1925 it spoke about the British seamen's strike. It raised the familiar catch cry: 'Do not vote for Labor; the Corns will rule the country.' That is the history of what has been said over the years. That is what the Liberal Governments have done each time an election was to be held. Novices here have spoken about left wing members of the Labor Party. Who are the left wing members? I have been a member of the Party for over 50 years. All I know is that I have been a member of the Labor Party.

How will the Government extricate itself from the position in which it finds itself today? It has placed the nation in a position in which it should hang its head in shame because its security organisation, acting outside the ambit of its powers, has belittled itself and the nation by obtaining papers on trade matters from another nation's embassy. Instead of trying to win a political argument the Government should stand up to something of which it ought to be ashamed. The people will not be convinced that there is nothing wrong simply because the Government continues to sling mud. I am reminded of a writing by Samuel Johnson that patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel. That is all honourable senators opposite know. They want to think that they are super-patriots and that they are the only people who guard the welfare of the nation. There are others. I remember what happened in the war years. Honourable senators opposite talk about what the Government did for the nation. I remember when the Government had to be voted out of office by some of its own supporters in the early part of the last war because it could not run the country. I also remember that, in order to keep in office since then, it dummied up the Petrov affair. I also remember that at one election the Government bought the votes of one section of the community by allocating less than £2m for science blocks. I also remember an exPrime Minister sending the then Minister for Supply to the United States of America to buy aeroplanes to save the country.

talk.start.para: - What plane was that?

- That was the famous Fill. We have not seen it yet. In order to fool the people the Government arranged to have large American planes visit certain cities a fortnight before the pending election. The Government got away with slinging mud and not answering its critics then, but it will not get away with it now unless it makes an explanation of this whole affair. The whole business is crook and the Government knows that it is. The Government is a party to it because it will not answer. If it has any love left for the nation, if it wants to see the nation hold its head up as it should, it should investigate the whole affair. It is no good saying that the allegations are not true. It is no good saying, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Anderson) said - and personally I have great respect for him - that we cannot discuss anything about security. All we seek is an assurance that members of ASIO will act within the ambit of the powers bestowed upon them by their charter. They should ensure that the country is secure, but they should not make us hang our heads in shame because they put a young lady in the Japanese Embassy to make extra carbon copies of letters. How wrong is that? How will we be respected in the world of commerce today? A lot has been said about the Japanese trade treaty, how Japan is helping in our development and what it is doing in Western Australia. I know what I would do if I were they, and if it suited me. I would say: 'If we are friends play the game as it ought to be played and play it decently'. Last night one honourable senator opposite rose in one of his typically heroic efforts to try to bolster up the stocks of the Government. He is new in politics. He comes from my own State. He has to learn. He can throw mud, and he throws it, because he knows that within a short space of time he will shift to a vacant seat on the front bench.
- He thinks he will.

- I think he will, too, because sooner or later the Government will learn that it cannot put all the responsibility on the shoulders of one or two of its members all the time. This is not the last that the Government will hear about this. We want the matter cleaned up.
- It is not the first that we have heard about it, either.
- I will be interested to hear where the honourable senator stands in relation to the matter. I do not mind.
- He will be on the right side, for sure.

- He will be on the right side as regards numbers. One would expect a statement from the Government on the matter. Where do we go from here? We should clean this matter up. lt is no good the Government saying that the allegations are not true. The last thing the Government would expect its friends to be saying is that it has something to answer. The Government may expect that from the Opposition, but it would not expect it from the people who put their columns at the Government's disposal at the right time. I hope, in the interests of the nation and in the interests of everyone here, that, the guilty person - and there is a guilty person because the party did hand over extra copies of the letters - is identified. I do not want to hurt Hoffmann at all. The funniest remark I have heard was Senator Scott's statement that after the man had lost a $7,000 a year job the Department or the Minister helped him to get a $9,000 a year job.
- He got a good reference.

- I do not know. Leave him alone. I suppose he has his own worries. But the whole matter is so funny that it is an insult to the intelligence of honourable senators to hear the Leader of the Government say that he has nothing to answer. I believe he has. I believe it will help the nation if he answers as quickly as he can.

- The Senate should be grateful tonight to Senator Kennelly for again raising this matter. I think Senator McManus's comment was fairly apt this afternoon when he spoke about the Tales from Hoffmann'. Perhaps we should go back to the music hall song entitled 'Who Threw the Turtle Skins in Senator Murphy's Chowder' because that is what this matter has developed into. I am also grateful to Senator Kennelly for reminding me of the sort of nonsense we have heard tossed up by the Labor Party about this subject for years and years.

speech.para: There is no doubt in my mind that the Hoffmann affair has been trotted out as a vehicle to attack the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. It was trotted out for that and no other reason. It is all right for Senator Kennelly to accuse people on this side of the chamber of mud slinging but he would be well advised to realise who started the mud slinging. It was started by the Opposition as an exercise to denigrate ASIO. There are no two ways about this. The entire attack has been based on this. When one recalls the debate on this subject, which commenced 4 or 5 sitting days ago, it included an attack on Hansard for allegedly producing false pulls of what the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Scott) had said; then the Public Service Board was under attack and then the Minister was under attack. But ASIO has been mentioned throughout the entire attack. This debate has been a convenient vehicle to denigrate the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation.

Why is this so? It is all very well for Senator Kennelly to come into this chamber and pose as the great patriot. But one wonders why, if he is the great patriot, he wants to attack ASIO. This is what I want to know. He is saying that the Government has something to hide. Ministers have been quite frank in their answers about what has happened, yet Senator Kennelly goes on and on with the same old story. The same thing has been trotted out hour after hour. There has been a continuing attack on ASIO.

talk.start.para: - What is the honourable senator telling us?

- We even had Senator Wheeldon going back to 1964 or 1965. We have heard Opposition senators going back to an episode which they allege happened when a woman was employed some 7 or 8 years ago. These things have been trotted up as a vehicle to attack ASIO.
- Are you proving what he said is wrong?

- It is quite a simple proposition, as I see it. The Opposition is making the accusation and therefore it should make it stick. For a long time we have heard Senator Murphy prating on and on this chamber about the Declaration of Human Rights. However, irrespective of the modern versions which arise out of the discussions of that organisation known as the United Nations, there is a very old principle of British law to the effect that the onus of proof is on the prosecution.

speech.para: Does the Opposition wish to throw aside that principle? This is what it is attempting to do. Opposition senators are picking out some newspaper allegations and are saying: Here is some proof - now you answer it.'

If this is the way that members of the Opposition attempt to build a case and if this is the way in which they seek to represent their unions in industrial advocacy, then it is no wonder that trade unions complain that they cannot get a fair go from our arbitration and conciliation courts. If the presentation of the unions' case is as good as has been the presentation by the Opposition of this affair in this chamber, then God help the people that they are supposed to represent. The Opposition's standard of advocacy and presentation of a case is deplorably low, Mr President.

talk.start.para: - You would be a judge.

- If this is the standard of advocacy, if all the Opposition can do is to abuse the other side, then it does not say much for honourable senators opposite. All they have done is to trot along here with allegation after allegation, attacking various officers of the Parliament and of the Public Service Board, jumping from one to the other. As the Opposition has failed with one attack it has tried to attack another target. Well, Mr President, I do not think it says much for the validity of the Opposition's case if that is the most it can do.

speech.para: We keep coming back to the point I made earlier when I said that this is purely a vehicle to attack the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. The matter has been raised for no other reason. The Opposition has no other purpose in mind than to promote this in an attempt to uncover some scandal which it has never been able to prove existed. Yet it is quite convenient for its members to attack along these lines. Senator Kennelly has dragged in another point by saying that there is a letter. Which letter is this? He says that there is a letter in existence which was read within the precincts of the Parliament. I think it fair enough that he should disclose who has the letter and why it is not being read. Again there is this mysterious evidence. Is this another allegation? Is there something else floating around the Parliament? Not one answer has been given about this. What are we doing? Are we having a trial by ambush? Is the Opposition attempting to trot out matter after matter in an attempt to confuse the issue? Mr President, with respect to all that Senator Kennelly said tonight, I am afraid that so far as the Opposition is concerned it has failed in its attempt throughout this whole sorry business. We have had this subject brought up night after night and to what stage have we advanced? We have come to the crux of the matter, as stated by Senator Kennelly tonight. The crux of this matter is definitely an attack on ASIO. We can forget about turtle skins; we can forget about Mr Hoffmann; we can forget about the Hansard reporter allegedly doing wrong things when reporting the Minister for Customs and Excise and we come back to ASIO.

Mr President,I feel sorry for the Opposition. The Parliament has been in recess for some 2 or 3 months and it appears that this is the best sort of vehicle that the Opposition can raise as a matter of national importance in this Parliament. There are great questions to be debated, such as the defence statement. As Senator Marriott pointed out quite rightly this afternoon, the Opposition has chickened out and has run away again. The Opposition does not want to get down to debating the great national issues. It would rather dash off and talk about turtle skins. Is this the sort of mentality that the Opposition possesses? It is no wonder, as Senator Kennelly said, quite rightly, that my distinguished colleague, Senator Greenwood, will one day sit on the front bench. We all hope that this is so. If the attack launched tonight by the Opposition is an indication of the thinking of the 'Labor Party then it will be in opposition for a long long time and Senator Greenwood, who will be in this chamber for many years to come, may expect that he will naturally gravitate over the next 20 or 30 years to the front bench of this Senate. He has all the time in the world because the Labor Party will be staying in opposition for the next 20 years. It will be sitting on that side of the chamber for the next 20 years because I am quite convinced that the Australian people will not fall for the sort of nonsense that has been trotted out here night after night about the tales from Hoffmann.

This is a fairly sorry affair, Mr President. It is regrettable that we have spent most of this day talking about an alleged urgency motion and are now dealing with this matter. These great patriots on the other side talk about what they did in the war and all the rest of the clap-trap that we have heard tonight. So many of my colleagues on this side of the chamber were otherwise engaged in those times on the Queen's business. One would have thought that these great patriots on the Opposition side would have wanted to debate the defence statement or the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Gorton) on Australia's attitude in our far north. But no; they would much prefer to attack the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. If this is the best that the Opposition can come up with then I repeat that the Labor Party will be in opposition for a long time.

talk.start.para: - The honourable senator has said that five times.

- It is regrettable that the Opposition must indulge in these oldfashioned histrionics and try to advance a case built up on allegations from newspapers. I regret that the time of the Senate has again been wasted on this subject.

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

subdebateinfo.title: Oil Search Subsidies - Oil Drilling Leases

talk.start.para: - In conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

quote.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: - I wish to raise a very important matter but I do not propose to detain the Senate for any length of time. I advised the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Scott) representing the Minister for National Development that I proposed to speak this evening on what appeared to be the misuse of Commonwealth subsidies paid in connection with the search for oil. It will be necesary for me to raise a number of points. I am mindful of the fact that it is not permissible to criticise the activities of a State Parliament in this place. Therefore I propose to deal with that matter only insofar as the funds of Commonwealth taxpayers are affected indirectly by the payment of subsidies to encourage and assist the search for oil in this country.

speech.para: I think all honourable senators are aware, even at this early stage of my remarks, of the matter to which I intend to make reference. I wish to refer first to the Artesian Oil Co. Ltd which started off originally with a capital of $4 and which subsequently attracted an oil search subsidy of $22,800. Working on the farm-out system, a drilling company known as Lucky Strike Drilling Co. spent something like $70,000 over a period of 3 years in the search for oil. I might say that the original $4 was the total investment at that particular time by Johannes Bjelke-Petersen who, today, is Premier of the State of Queensland. The subsidy that was attracted by the combined drilling and exploration operations that I mentioned a moment ago was $22,800. During the signing up process in a subsequent amalgamation or takeover by a company known as Exoil (NL), this company received a refund of something like $60,000 allegedly as compensation for its oil search activities.

This meant that somewhere along the line the sum of $12,000 changed hands, to put it in simple terms, twice. Ordinarily, in view of the search, or lack of search, that had taken place, this $12,000 should have been returned to the Government. I am not aware that it has been returned. Perhaps the Minister representing the Minister for National Development can tell me that in fact a refund of $12,000 was made to the Government. I hope he can. If no refund was made perhaps the Minister can tell us where the money may have gone. Perhaps the transaction may be looked upon by some as a proper one. Did this money go into the pockets of certain persons associated with the companies involved? One significant fact about all this is that, according to the documents available, the personal expenditure by Mr Bjelke-Petersen in this fantastic oil search was something like $170.

I take the Senate back now to the year 1959. Apparently at that time the gentleman to whom I have referred filled in a tax return for the year which showed the sum of £140 3s 9d as being proceeds from the sale of his interest in the lease in question which, incidentally, was in northern Queensland. From memory, the lease is described as Authority 69P. Some months later the taxation authorities contacted Mr Bjelke-Petersen. I am quoting now from documents which are available to the public. It was explained that there had been an error and that in fact the amount of £140 3s 9d should have read £14,039. There was a very big mistake and the tax consultants were blamed. Permission was obtained for an amended statement to be submitted.

I would now like to refer to notes taken from the transcript. I will be as brief as I possibly can and will refer to only the relevant sections. This is a statement made by Mr Bjelke-Peterson and it sets out how his investment in the fantastic oil search was made up. The document states:

quote.para: We spent a full week flying the area from the 14th to 19th December 1958. Hours flown 25.
Cost: As it was my own aircraft and pilot, the cost to me was not so great.

speech.para: The document sets out the wages of the pilot at £25 - this would be $50 in today's currency; the fuel used at 8 galls per hour at £50; and hotel expenses at £10. The document continued:

quote.para: During this period we flew to various points across the width of the area. Our investigations took us also to the furthest north-eastern corner on the Saxby River, and through the length of the area in different directions until finally reaching the eastern boundary.
The other expenses were in connection -with the trip. I also had to go to the area which I flew by passenger plane via Townsville to Hughenden to inspect drilling sites . . . fare £24.

On this occasion I also flew some hundreds of miles with a friend, Mr Jack Smultz of Hughenden with whom I stayed. He flew me in his twin engine aircraft. I paid for all the fuel and running expenses, a total of £26 10s Od.
On that occasion I inspected by car possible drilling sites in the area.

I also made two trips to Sydney at my own expense to interview the Directors of Longreach Oil Search, and the Directors of Oil Drilling Exploration with a view to having them participate in assisting us in our drilling, and thus throughout I spent many weeks of personal endeavour, particularly in the Mackay area, seeking to bring the drilling operations to a successful conclusion.

speech.para: My conclusion is that apparently a total sum of about $170 was involved. If ohe peruses the records of these three companies it is obvious, of course, that there has been a very, very substantial return made on the original very minor investment of $4. I think that this situation is deserving of a pretty thorough investigation to see where the $12,000 has gone. If it has been returned to the Government I would be happy to have that explanation.

We ought to look at this matter from another angle because it was mentioned in various places today and at other times that licences for off-shore areas are currently being held up for some reason or other. I have very good reason to believe that one of the licences is included in the Premier's chosen company, that there were 18 other applicants and it is a glamour lease on the Great Barrier Reef. 1 believe that if this is the way subsidies are to be used to enrich people personally - to enrich those who participate in small mushroom companies that grow into major companies overnight - the Commonwealth Government will have to be much more discreet and searching before it decides to pay out these subsidies on the scale on which this subsidy was apparently paid out, and in circumstances such as those to which I have referred.

It seems ridiculous that such a small sum should be spent by one individual and the ultimate turnover to the company and to the individual runs into many thousands of dollars. The facts I have stated can be verified from any of the documents I have quoted. Perhaps Senator Greenwood, who was doing some challenging a moment ago, would be interested in this. The documents I referred to are associated with the appeal to the taxation people. I suggest in all sincerity that this is a matter deserving of very deep and searching investigation.

talk.start.para: - The first thing that should be noted, if there is anything to be made plain in reference to the matter that Senator Keeffe has brought up on the adjournment, is that legal proceedings were concluded in the High Court of Australia in regard to the taxability of the income of the Premier of Queensland as far back as 1963. The miserableness of the motives of a senator who can rise tonight without giving any statement to this Government of what he proposed to say in substance-
- Mr President, I object to that statement. I advised the Minister.
- To what is the honourable senator objecting?
- Senator Wright said that I gave no notice. I did.
- Order! The honourable senator can make a personal explanation later.

- I accept the honourable senator's statement that he indicated to the Minister that he proposed to raise this subject, but he did not give to the Government any summarised or adequate statement of the matters of finance that he proposed to raise. It is quite obvious that the only purpose that Senator Keeffe had in raising this matter tonight was to smear a man, whose responsibility is complete and adequate in another Parliament, by ex parte insinuations in this chamber on a subject more than 6 years old. On his own statement of the facts it originated 10 years ago. The irony of it is the miserableness of the matter as presented by Senator Keeffe. This is brought in at a time when the State parliamentarian concerned is about to engage in an election in Queensland. The Premier of Queensland has made his own statement in the Press today. I have not had an opportunity to read it. I did not know that it would come within my responsibility to hear Senator Keeffe's statement tonight. I concede that the honourable senator's remarks are pertinent insofar as there is some suggestion that subsidies paid by the Commonwealth Government have gone to a company. The honourable senator does not suggest that they have not been refunded; he inquires whether they have been refunded and whether there is an obligation to refund. Of course, the matter having been stated here, inquiry will be made.

speech.para: With regard to the suggestion of evasion of income tax, I had the opportunity yesterday to read the High Court report on a question as to the taxability of some matter arising out of mining investments by the Premier of Queensland. That was reported in 1963 Argus Law Reports. It will be noted that Senator Keeffe said that he relied upon matters accessible to the public. I presume that he was referring to the documents that are filed in the registry and stated in the Law Reports. I hope that the honourable senator will not presume to discuss in this Senate, or expect us to inquire of the Commissioner of Taxation or any of his officers, the personal details of any taxpayer in this country, high or low. Not only is that within the confidential custody of the Taxation Branch as a matter of acknowledgment on all sides, but the statute of this Parliament specifically enjoins that neither the Commissioner nor any officer shall make available to any person any information with regard to the private affairs of a taxpayer on whom we have placed the obligation to render a return as to his income. If anything further is to be said after the High Court has decided the taxability of the taxpayer concerned, I have no doubt that that too would be inquired into by the Treasurer and dealt with in due course.

It should be stated further that the issue that came before the High Court was as to whether the receipt was of an income nature or was in the nature of capital. I think it is only fair to say that that question is very indefinite in its definition and in many cases is a line ball, especially in modern commerce. The very fact that a man comes before an appeal tribunal, either at his own instance or at the instance of the Commissioner to contest the question as to whether money received in certain circumstances is in the nature of income or in the nature of capital is no indication of want of integrity or any questionable bona fides. It is a common experience that can be shared by any taxpayer who has a difference of opinion on that very indefinite field of law in relation to which the Commissioner and even the High Court in recent cases have gone out of their way to acknowledge that the criteria are very indefinite and uncertain.

That is as much as I need say with regard to this stale and miserable insinuation that Senator Keeffe characteristically has brought forward in the Senate 6 or 10 years - at least 6 years - after this matter was publicly reported in the law reports of the High Court of Australia.

talk.start.para: - Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation. Senator Wright accused me of not giving reasonable notice that I intended to speak on this matter. I was unaware that Senator Scott had been deposed as the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. I informed Senator Scott that I intended to speak on this matter tonight, and I believe that, as a matter of courtesy, I have complied with all the forms of the Senate.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
